titleStmt.title: Hierarchical Face Representations 1 Modular Serial-Parallel Network for Hierarchical Facial Representations

affiliation.orgName: Professor Grand Valley State University Psychology Department

analytic.title: Hierarchical Face Representations 1 Modular Serial-Parallel Network for Hierarchical Facial Representations

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: While some evidence suggests that faces are perceived holistically, research on the neural organization of the visual system and people's subjective experiences indicate that face parts can also be analyzed individually. Thus, advances in theories of face perception are met with two major challenges: How can hierarchical face representations be used to integrate holistic and analytic encoding within the same framework? And how can the stages of face processing be integrated with higher-level cognitive processes, such as memory and decision-making, that are recruited during facial perception? We propose a novel computational framework termed the Modular Serial-Parallel Network (MSPN), which synthesizes several perceptual and cognitive approaches including memory representations, signal detection theory, rule-based decision-making, mental architectures (serial and parallel processing), random walks, and process interactivity. MSPN provides a computational modeling account of four stages in face perception: (a) representational, (b) decisional, (c) logical-rule implementation, and (d) modular stochastic accrual of information and can account for both choice probabilities and response-time predictions. We used MSPN to explore and validate theories across multiple paradigms: (i) in the composite face paradigm, our analyses revealed support for holistic encoding in aligned conditions and analytic encoding in misaligned conditions providing an explanation for the Congruency × Alignment interaction; (ii) in the part-to-whole paradigm, analytic encoding and holistic encoding were equally successful in accurately capturing facial feature recognition; (iii) in a new study of the other-race effect, MSPN showed an impressive ability in fitting the individual choice RT distributions over other models. The application of MSPN suggests that facial processing varies based on the task, that holistic perception does not necessarily imply complete pooling into a single face object, but MSPN can reveal the precise nature of processing that gives rise to holistic effects in different paradigms.

div.p: Faces are a critical source of social information, and the ability to accurately identify and interpret facial features is essential for successful social interaction.

Identifying a person's face allows us to better adapt to social situations, improve our social skills, find a romantic partner, or recognize an enemy. It is not surprising that many researchers support the idea that face perception is special and different from the perception of other visual objects (e.g., Ellis & Young, 1989;Biederman & Kalocsais, 1997;Golby et al., 2001;McKone, Kanwisher & Duchaine, 2007;Leibo, Mutch, & Poggio, 2011;McKone, & Robbins, 2011;but cf. Gauthier & Logothetis, 2000;Bukach, Gauthier, & Tarr, 2006).

Both face and object perception involve the use of hierarchical representations, in which a face or object is represented as both a whole and as individual parts. For instance, in our everyday experience, we can easily shift our attention between different parts of an object or face, and from the individual parts to the entire object or face.

There is neurophysiological evidence supporting the idea that the visual cortex has a hierarchical organization of neurons with receptive fields that increase in size from simple, elementary features to whole objects or faces (e.g., Hubel & Wiesel, 1959;Riesenhuber & Poggio, 1999;Hochstein & Ahissar 2002;Nichols, Betts, & Wilson, 2010;Zhen, Fang & Liu, 2013;Henriksson, Mur & Kriegeskorte, 2015;Erez, et al., 2016;Haas, Schwarzkopf, Alvarez, Lawson, Henriksson, Kriegeskorte, & Rees, 2016;Wang, Zhen, Song, Huang, Kong, & Liu, 2016;Nestor, Plaut & Behrmann, 2016;Goffaux, Duecker, Hausfeld, Schiltz & Goebel, 2016;Fan, et al., 2020;Zhang, Jiang, Song, Zhang, & He, 2021;Ricci & Serre 2020; see also Tanaka & Farah, 1993;cf. Rossion, et al., 2011). This suggests that the brain processes visual information in a hierarchical manner, with lower-level neurons responsible for detecting basic features and higher-level neurons responsible for integrating these features into more complex representations of objects and faces. This hierarchical organization allows us to process visual information at different levels of granularity, from individual features to whole objects or faces.

To understand how the brain processes faces, researchers have proposed the opposing concepts of analytic and holistic encoding. The holistic encoding hypothesis suggests that the brain creates a new, integrated representation of a face by combining the individual features of the face into a single unit (for the comprehensive review see . Decisions about the identity or other aspects of the face are based on this emergent, holistic representation. Analytic encoding, on the other hand, refers to the idea that the brain processes faces by analyzing individual featural units separately. With analytic encoding, decisions and behaviors are driven by values representing individual features rather than any combination of those features. Effects consistent with holistic processing are then, theoretically, the result of overlearned, automatic attentional strategies applied to these individual features (Richler, Palmeri & Gauthier, 2012;Richler, Wong & Gauthier, 2011).

Various methods used to test the holistic encoding hypothesis involve manipulating the degree of interference expected from holistic processing and measure the sensitivity of the perceptual system to these changes. This approach has been used with a variety of methods, including altering the wholeness of a face through feature displacements (e.g., Tanaka & Farah, 1993), hiding or removing face parts (e.g., Tanaka & Farah, 1993), face inversion (e.g., Yin, 1969), splitting and misaligning face halves (e.g., Young, Hellawell, & Hay, 1987), comparing the recognition of individual parts (e.g., Tanaka & Farah, 1993), studying Thatcherized-effects arising from inverting individual features (e.g., Thompson, 1980), and scrambling the face (e.g., Collishaw & Hole, 2000; see Maurer, Le Grand, & Mondloch, 2002 for a review). Inference in these paradigms typically involves first identifying performance differences between upright, aligned faces and other conditions (e.g., inverted, misaligned faces or non-face objects), and then interpreting these differences as indicators of holistic processing.

One of the key limitations of previous work in the domain of holistic face perception is the use of vaguely defined theoretical constructs. Many studies have relied on concepts such as failure of selective attention as a marker of holistic processing, yet this may result from multiple theoretical mechanisms that mimic each other . Specifically, failure to attend to individual facial features may result not only from the holistic "gluing" of features into an integrated perceptual representation but instead from an overlearned attentional strategy. The lack of clarity regarding which specific cognitive operations contribute to holistic processing has led to conceptual ambiguity, making it difficult to determine whether different studies are measuring the same underlying phenomenon. Furthermore, neither of these accounts say anything about the underlying processing system -for instance, whether processing is serial or parallel (Fific & Townsend, 2010).

A second limitation of prior theoretical approaches is the tendency to overgeneralize theoretical constructs without providing a clear rationale for how different processing structures interact. This overgeneralization reduces the falsifiability of models, as different mechanisms may be invoked to explain the same empirical results without a clear decision rule for determining which mechanism applies in a given context. An example of this issue is the Interactive Configural Processing Theory (Maurer, Le Grand, & Mondloch, 2002), which proposes that face processing involves multiple levels of featural, configural, and holistic information. However, this theory does not specify how these subsystems interact or which conditions lead to the activation of one type of processing over another. Without a clear decision structure, such models become overly flexible, making them difficult to test rigorously.

A third major issue is model mimicry, where different theoretical accounts can produce similar behavioral patterns, leading to misinterpretation of holistic effects. A notable example is the partial version of the composite face task (Goffaux & Rossion, 2006;Rossion & Boremanse, 2008), where participants must determine whether one half of a face remains the same while ignoring the other half. The common inference from this task is that holistic processing causes interference between aligned face halves.

However, accuracy differences between aligned and misaligned faces can also be explained by response biases rather than genuine holistic integration (Gauthier & Bukach, 2007). Furthermore, alignment effects could be driven by multiple cognitive mechanisms, including increased parallel processing, exhaustive processing, or failures of inhibition for aligned faces. The presence of model mimicry in these paradigms highlights the need for formal computational models that explicitly test competing mechanisms rather than assuming that behavioral differences necessarily indicate holistic processing.

Finally, a significant limitation of prior work is the reliance on single dependent measures, often focusing solely on accuracy while neglecting other critical behavioral indicators. This approach limits the falsifiability of models and prevents a comprehensive analysis of cognitive and perceptual processes. For example, studies that only analyze response accuracy fail to account for trade-offs between speed and accuracy, which provide important diagnostic evidence for distinguishing between different processing architectures. Even when both reaction times and accuracy are collected, they are often analyzed separately rather than being jointly modeled within the same theoretical framework. Without a quantitative structure that links both response accuracy and reaction times, previous studies have struggled to rigorously validate their theoretical claims, leaving open the possibility that alternative explanations remain untested.

Taken together, these limitations highlight the need for a more rigorous and computationally explicit approach to the study of holistic face perception. In the current paper, we propose the Modular Serial-Parallel Network (MSPN), explicitly designed to alleviate and address each of these limitations of previous approaches by providing a unified framework that formally specifies processing architectures, decision-making mechanisms, and the interactions between perceptual and memory processes, thus enabling stronger theoretical validation and greater model falsifiability.

Modular Serial-Parallel Networks (MSPN) In this section, we introduce the Modular Serial-Parallel Network (MSPN) model, to provide a common framework for integrating analytic and holistic encoding with cognitive processes such as memory and decision-making. MSPN is a complete processing model that can account for response accuracy, choice preference, and response times (RTs) in tasks with binary response outcomes, although it can be extended to tasks with multiple alternatives or continuous responses (see e.g., Ratcliff & McKoon, 2020;Smith, 2019;van Ravenzwaaij, et al., 2020;Zhou, et al., 2021). The model synthesizes advances in RT modelling (Busemeyer, 1985;Link, 1975;Luce, 1986;Ratcliff, 1978;Ratcliff & Rouder, 1998;Townsend & Ashby, 1983), mental architecture modeling (Kantowitz, 1974;Schweickert, 1992;Sternberg, 1969;Townsend, 1984), non-parametric measures of systems identification (Townsend & Nozawa, 1995;, and theories of decision making in perceptual categorization (Ashby & Townsend, 1986;Ashby & Gott, 1988;Fifić et al., 2010). Note: The stimuli are composed of two dimensions, X -lips-to-nose separation and Y -eye-to-eye separation, with four values per dimension, combined orthogonally to produce the 16 combinations of the stimulus set. The central face indicates a spatial location of the reference face that was used to establish decision criteria for responding on both featural dimensions. The stimuli in the lower-right quadrant of the space, separated by dotted lines, are the members of the "target" category (Category A), whereas the remaining stimuli are the members of the other category (Category B). Membership in the A category is described in terms of a conjunctive rule -(both facial features are larger than that of the reference face), and membership in the B category is described in terms

div.head: "AND"
div.p: At the representational level, perceptual objects, such as faces, are decomposed into a set of elementary visual features. These featural representations are stored as point values in a multi-dimensional face space, with each dimension representing a different feature. There is noise associated with each featural representation, modeled as a normal distribution around the true feature value (Figure 1, Left -the axes "Memory representation"). This is intended to capture the idea of single feature tuning neurons in the primary (or lower-level) visual system, which are thought to be important for early processing of visual information (Hubel & Wiesel, 1959;Riesenhuber & Poggio, 1999).

At the decisional level, the cognitive system establishes stimulus-response associations and determines how to segregate featural representations based on task expectations. This is achieved through setting a decision criterion, which partitions a featural dimension into two response regions. In categorization choice tasks, each region is associated with a different binary decision outcome (Figure 1 left, category A and B). For example, as illustrated in Figure 1, if a featural activation falls to the right of the decision line (dotted line), this is interpreted as evidence in favor of category A, while activations to the left are interpreted as evidence in favor of category B. This process is related to signal detection theory (Green & Swets, 1966) and its multidimensional extensions (Ashby & Townsend, 1986;Ashby & Gott, 1988), which propose that decision-making is based on the evaluation of sensory evidence against a criterion.

In the next stage, logical rule implementation, a system can use different logical combinations of micro-decisions on separate features representations to decide which on a response (see e.g., Townsend & Nozawa, 1995;Fifić, Little & Nosofsky, 2010;. For example, if recognition requires all features to be analyzed, the system might use a conjunctive rule with an AND gate. This is also called an exhaustive stopping rule. On the other hand, if recognition only needs one feature to be recognized, the system might use a disjunctive rule with an OR gate, which is called a selfterminating stopping rule. In this case, the system can make a final decision based on a single feature, regardless of whether other features are available or not.

In the next section, we describe the modular stochastic accrual of information. In MSPN, we combined two extremely successful approaches to the modeling of RT data and response choices, namely the random-walk and mental-architecture approaches.

The core of these ideas was recently published as the logical rule models first introduced in perceptual categorization by Fifić, Little, & Nosofsky (2010; see also Little, 2012;Blunden, Hammond, Howe & Little, 2022;Fong, Blunden, Garrett, Smith & Little, 2024) and tested across several experiments (Blunden, Howe & Little, 2020;Blunden, Wang, Griffiths & Little, 2015;Cheng et al., 2018;Fong, et al., 2024;Little, Nosofsky & Denton, 2011;Little, Nosofsky, Donkin & Denton, 2013;Moneer, Wang & Little, 2016;Yang, Wang, Chang,, et al., 2019).

The random walk (RW) is a stochastic accumulator of noisy evidence over time that makes discrete steps over discrete time units. In the random walk, the observer establishes a threshold representing the amount of evidence that is needed to make a category A or B decision. At each step, a random walk process collects a small amount of evidence coming from activated noisy memory or sensory representation. The likelihood of accumulating either evidence for A or B is determined by stepping probability p to Criterion A, and 1-p toward Criterion B. The parameter p defines how likely is that, at each step of evidence accumulation, the sampled evidence from memory representation supports either A or B decision. In MSPN (e.g., Fifić, Little & Nosofsky, 2010), the value of p is proportional to the area under the normally distributed featural representation, bounded by the decision criterion and by the end of the tail of that distribution (Figure 2) on the featural dimension. It is important to note that the stepping probabilities are not treated as free parameters in MSPN (e.g., Fifić, Little & Nosofsky, . 2010) but are indirectly derived from the parameters describing memory and decision-making process. 1

1 We use the random walk model as a convenient approximation to the continuous accumulation of evidence and prediction of response time distributions (e.g., Ratcliff & McKoon, 2008). Other approximations are possible including linear ballistic accumulation (Brown & Heathcote, 2008) which has been used in some applications of the logical rule models (Moneer et al., 2016;Cheng et al., 2018).

We adopt the random walk approach here because it provides a tractable way to simulate interactions between processing channels. Figure 2. A face presented on a two-dimensional space representing lips-to-nose and eye-to-eye, respectively Note: Each facial property is represented as a noisy distribution around the mean value N(M, σ), separated by a decision bound D, into two response regions. Each region contributes to evidence sampling toward one of the two category responses A and B. For each facial property, the sampling regions are proportional to the area under the normal distribution so that in 1 = ∫

, and 1 = 1 − 1 . The stepping probabilities 1 and 2 , are used in two separate random walk processes, associated with each facial property, and it is important to see that their values are determined by the properties of the normal distribution associated with the status of featural representations and the position of the decision bounds (D1 and D2).

In (I) sampling of the featural evidence will likely be congruent at each time step as both 1 and 2 , are larger than .5 (shaded regions), which means that both random walks are more likely to sample evidence for category A then for category B. In contrast, as shown in (II) sampling of the featural evidence will likely be incongruent at each time step, as the first property is more likely to sample evidence for category A membership, while the second property is more likely to sample evidence for B category.

If the evidence from a sampled feature falls into region A, the random walk takes a step in the direction of Criterion A; otherwise, it takes a step in the direction of Criterion B. The final decision about whether the stimulus belongs to category A or category B is determined by whether the evidence reached Criterion A or Criterion B, respectively. The time required to make a decision using the random walk model is determined by the number of steps needed to complete the process.

To determine an overall response, potentially combining several random walks, a mental architecture is implemented. A mental architecture determines processing order of several random walks, each representing micro-decisions about separate facial features. In a serial architecture, the featural sources are analyzed in a strictly sequential fashion. Serial processing is represented as a series of sequential random walks ( Figure 1, on the right, at the top). If the decision rule is an AND rule, then the expected RT is the sum of the two random-walk evidence accumulation times RT=T1+T2; but if the decision rule is an OR rule, then the RT is determined by one of the random walks RT=T1, or RT=T2. In a parallel processing architecture, the series of featural sources are analyzed simultaneously, which is represented as a set of parallel random walks (Figure 1, on the right, in the middle). If the decision rule is an AND rule, the expected RT is the slowest time to process each feature, RT=Max(T1, T2); if the rule is an OR rule, then the expected processing time is the fastest processing time of the two features, RT=Min(T1,T2). 2

Finally, MSPN makes provisions for possible process dependency when multiple attributes from the same object are considered. The concept of process dependency means that the time needed to complete processing of a single attribute, depends on the time needed to process another attribute(s). The concept is non-trivial and several definitions of process dependency have been provided (Townsend & Ashby, 1983;Ashby, 1989;Colonius, 1990;Townsend & Thomas, 1994;Diederich, 1995;Usher, & McClelland, 2001;Dzhafarov, 2003;Townsend & Wenger, 2004;Kujala & Dzhafarov, 2008;Eidels, Houpt, Altieri, Pei & Townsend, 2011;Little, Eidels, Houpt, Garrett & Griffiths, 2019;Yang Altieri & Little, 2018;Yang, Wang, Chang, et. al. 2019;Zhang, Liu & Townsend, 2019;Townsend, & Liu, 2022). In MSPN, we will consider the version of the process dependency that has been typically considered within the parallel processing systems, dubbed the parallel-interactive model (Eidels, et al., 2011;Yang, Yang, Wang, Chang et al., 2019). In this approach, the interaction between two stochastic accumulators occurs when accumulators can communicate with each other during evidence accrual. We will consider how this communication is formalized in the framework of random walk accumulators. For example, two parallel random walks could exchange the sampled evidence toward one of the response boundaries, at each step during accumulation.

The concept of process dependence between separate processing units has been proposed in several cognitive models, including lateral inhibition models (Grossberg, 1976;McClelland & Rumelhart, 1981;Usher & McClelland, 2001;Usher & Ratcliff, 2001;Eidels, et al., 2011). The nature and extent of interaction in these models is often determined by the values of their free parameters. For instance, in many stochastic sequential sampling models, the type of interaction is determined by the values of the model's parameter matrix, such as in the stochastic General Recognition Theory (Ashby, 2000; see also Eidels et al, 2011). On the other hand, other theoretical approaches have fixed the type of interaction between stochastic accumulators based on the model's assumptions, such as the dynamic relationship between facilitatory inputs and inhibitory lateral connections between accumulators (as seen in Grossberg, 1976;McClelland & Rumelhart, 1981;Usher & Ratcliff 2001).

In MSPN, two random walk counters interact by exchanging evidence from activated features at each step of their random walk. For example, if the first random walk samples evidence for category A, its accumulator will increase by +1. If the second random walk also samples evidence for category A, the interactive module of MSPN will exchange the values, so that each random walk adds 1+1=2 to its accumulator, resulting in a faster "march" towards category A. On the other hand, if either of the random walks sample evidence for category B, their accumulators will decrease by 1.

In general, there are two possible scenarios when considering only two random walks for two features: (a) both random walks are accumulating evidence in the same direction (towards the same decision criteria; (Townsend & Wenger, 2004;Wenger & Townsend, 2001). They argued that the spectrum of processing from purely analytic to holistic can be defined by three fundamental cognitive properties: processing order, stopping rules, and process interdependency.
Processing Order (Serial < Parallel)
The first axiom states that serial processing, involving sequential feature analysis, is less holistic than parallel processing, which analyzes multiple features simultaneously.

Analytic processing, associated with piecemeal, feature-based representations, typically occurs as a slower serial process (e.g., Tversky & Krantz, 1969;Smith & Nielsen, 1970;Bradshaw & Wallace, 1971;Hole, 1994;Fitousi, 2021). In contrast, holistic processing assumes unitized representations and is often associated with fast parallel processing (Matthews, 1978;Sergent, 1984;Wenger & Townsend, 2001;Fifić & Townsend, 2010;Martens, Leuthold, & Schweinberger, 2010). MSPN formalizes this principle through its modular organization, allowing a probabilistic switch between serial and parallel processing modules from trial to trial. Specifically, the parameter pmod determines the likelihood of engaging either serial or parallel processing, enabling MSPN to quantify the degree of analytic versus holistic processing. Within the serial module, the processing order is further specified by the parameter pser, representing the probability of analyzing facial attributes in a particular sequence.

div.head: Stopping Rules (Terminating < Exhaustive)
div.p: Holistic encoding is characterized by exhaustive processing, which integrates all available feature-based evidence before reaching a decision (Wenger & Townsend, 2001). Conversely, analytic processing is associated with terminating stopping rules, allowing decisions to be made as soon as a single informative feature is sufficiently processed (Townsend & Nozawa, 1995;Innes-Ker, 2003;Fifić & Townsend, 2010;Yang, Fifić, Chang & Little, 2018). MSPN implements stopping rules explicitly through logical gates. An AND (exhaustive) rule requires completion of processing for all facial features before a response can be generated, reflecting holistic encoding. In contrast, an OR (self-terminating) rule allows responses based on the completion of only one feature's evaluation, characteristic of analytic processing. This distinction enables MSPN to explicitly determine whether observed holistic effects result from genuinely exhaustive processing or from another mechanism.
Process Interdependency (Independent < Interactive/Coactive)
The third axiom concerns feature interdependency. Independent feature processing,

where facial features are separately evaluated, is considered less holistic than interactive processing, in which features dynamically exchange information (Ashby, 1989;Townsend & Wenger, 2004;Eidels et al., 2011). MSPN quantifies feature interaction through the parameter pcross , which modulates the probability of evidence sharing between two random-walk accumulators within parallel processing channels.
At pcross = 0, features are processed independently without cross-talk. At intermediate levels (0 < pcross < 1), partial interaction occurs, reflecting graded holistic processing.

At maximal levels (pcross = 1), MSPN represents a fully integrated, coactive processing model analogous to a face template, in which all facial feature information seamlessly contributes to a unified perceptual decision. Thus, MSPN allows quantification and differentiation among these varying levels of feature interdependency and clearly distinguishes genuine holistic face processing from simpler forms of parallel or serial independent processing.

Memory Representation and Decision Components in MSPN: In addition to these foundational axioms, MSPN provides deeper insights into facial representation at both memory and decisional stages through its detailed parametric structure (for details see The importance of memory-level analyses connects directly to prominent theoretical accounts of holistic face perception. For example, the overlearned attention hypothesis (Chua, Richler, & Gauthier, 2014 and theories emphasizing failures of selective attention propose distinct underlying mechanisms driving holistic effects. MSPN's ability to quantify memory variance can help distinguish between these theories by determining whether changes in memory representations or decisional criteria underlie holistic effects.

At the evidence accumulation stage, MSPN explicitly models decision-making as a stochastic random-walk process, characterized by parameters such as stepping probabilities toward decision boundaries and decision thresholds (+A, -B). Although MSPN formally uses stepping probabilities to represent discrete evidence accumulation toward one of the decision boundaries, these probabilities closely align conceptually with drift rates, a term commonly employed in continuous drift-diffusion models. Drift rates, in general communication, refer to how quickly and reliably evidence accumulates for individual features, while decision thresholds represent how much cumulative evidence is required to commit to a categorical decision. These parameters allow MSPN to quantify precisely how different facial features contribute to overall perceptual judgments, revealing feature-specific differences in evidence strength and decisional criteria.

In sum, MSPN's explicit incorporation of processing order, stopping rules, process interactivity, and detailed parametric analyses of memory and decision-making provides a robust framework for validating and differentiating theoretical accounts of holistic face perception.

div.head: MSPN and Theories of Holistic Processing
div.p: Theories of face processing cannot be considered in isolation from the methods used to measure or operationalize various constructs and mechanisms that are assumed to underlie face processing. The term "holistic processing" is often evoked without providing a clear definition or by applying methods which varying target performance Hierarchical Face Representations in different ways (Richler et al., 2012). A strength of the present approach is that several theoretical constructs are formally represented in a single model. The purpose of this section is to expand their catalogue of theories by linking each theory or method to how it is instantiated within MSPN. Table 1 provides an overview of several and theoretical definitions of holistic processing. We discuss each in turn.

div.head: Face Templates
div.p: Faces processed using specialized holistic templates.
Maximal interaction (pcross = 1), indicating complete parallelinteractive integration.
Reduced interaction (pcross < 1) or serial self-terminating processing (pmod = 0).

div.head: Configural
div.p: Processing (Diamond & Carey, 1986) Faces contain emergent information in spatial configurations.
Changes in spatial properties influence memory representation means and variances.

Spatial properties not discriminated at memory representation level (no change in mean and variance). (Maurer, Le Grand, & Mondloch, 2002) Hierarchical integration of multiple configural and featural levels into a holistic percept.

div.head: Configural Processing Theory
div.p: Misaligned conditions: independent processing (pcross = 0); face inversion: alters interaction (pcross > 0).

div.head: Misaligned conditions:
div.p: interactive processing (pcross > 0); inversion does not alter interaction levels.

div.head: Interactive
div.p: Processing (Fifić & Townsend, 2010) Holistic perception emerges from graded interactivity among facial features.
Intermediate interaction values (0 < pcross < 1) and parallel processing (pmod = 1).
Purely serial (pmod = 0) or fully independent parallel processing (pcross = 0).

div.head: Overlearned
div.p: Attention (Chua, Richler, & Gauthier, 2014; Expertise-based attentional strategy causing holistic-like interference.
Learning increases drift rates and reduces memory variance; stable processing architecture and interactivity (pmod and pcross =constants).
Presence of purely serial (pmod = 0) architecture in holistic facial conditions

div.head: Failure of Selective
div.p: Attention Holistic effects result from inability to selectively process facial features.

div.head: Pure selective attention:
div.p: Serial, feature-based processing (pmod = 0, pcross = 0).

div.head: Failure of selective attention:
div.p: Presence of parallel processing (pmod > 0) or feature interaction (pcross > 0).

div.head: Theoretical Accounts of Holistic Face Processing and Their Validation within MSPN
div.p: Holistic face processing has been widely studied through different theoretical lenses, each proposing distinct mechanisms underlying the integration of facial features into a coherent percept. These accounts range from face templates and configural processing theories to interactive and attentional models. While these frameworks have provided valuable insights, they often lack a unified computational structure to formally test their predictions. The Modular Serial-Parallel Network (MSPN) offers a means to quantitatively assess these theories by specifying the extent of feature interactivity (pcross), processing architecture (pmod ), memory variance, and evidence accumulation parameters, including decisional parameters. Below, we discuss key theoretical perspectives on holistic processing and how MSPN can serve as a tool for their validation and falsification.

1. Face Template Hypothesis: One of the most prominent ways to understand holistic face processing, stemming from Gestalt ideas about the benefits of whole configurations, is with recourse to the idea that the parts of the faces are pooled or integrated into a unitary whole. That is, the individual parts of the face along with their configuration and second-order characteristics (e.g., spatial relations between parts) are pooled into a single object. The notion that faces are processed as whole-face templates falls into this category.

Evidence in favor of face templates comes from tasks showing that face inversion impairs identification relative to upright face processing (Maurer, Le Grand, & Mondloch, 2002;Valentine, 1988;Yin, 1969). One argument is that the individual parts and their organization are identical in an upright face compared to an inverted face; consequently, the impairment caused by inversion must be because inverted faces do not match the preferred template orientation (McKone & Yovel, 2009).

Alternatively, inverted faces may be processed less efficiently than upright faces because the automatic allocation of attention is disrupted by inversion (Curby & Gauthier, 2009;Sekular et al., 2004;Richler et al., , 2012. In support of the latter argument, inverted faces can reveal a composite face task interaction (Cheng et al., 2018), but this has been shown to arise later in the processing time course . Gold et al. (2012) tested whether recognizing whole faces provides additional benefits beyond recognizing individual parts by using an "integration index." This index compares actual performance to that predicted by optimal integration (Bayesian integrator). A value of 1 indicates optimal integration, while values greater than 1 suggest additional benefits from processing the whole face. Gold et al. found values slightly below 1 for both upright and inverted faces, suggesting no advantage for wholeface integration. Richler et al. (2012) 2. Configural Processing Theory: The configural processing theory (Diamond & Carey, 1986) extends beyond the face template model by emphasizing that emergent spatial relationships among facial features provide additional information critical for recognition. This theory suggests that upright faces are processed by encoding secondorder spatial relationships, which are disrupted by face inversion and other transformations such as misalignment (Thompson, 1980). Unlike the face template hypothesis, which assumes that face perception is based on a predefined holistic representation, configural processing theory argues that face recognition benefits from the explicit encoding of spatial relationships between features rather than a fixed template.

A related definition of holistic processing posits that the specific configuration of an upright face conveys additional information that enhances recognition (Diamond & Carey, 1986;Rhodes et al., 1993;Searcy & Bartlett, 1996;Leder & Bruce, 2000). This is demonstrated in the Thatcher illusion (Thompson, 1980), where local feature distortions (e.g., inverted eyes and mouth) appear grotesque when a face is upright but go unnoticed when the face is inverted. This illusion supports the claim that face perception relies on the processing of global spatial relationships rather than isolated features. Other face manipulations, such as inversion or misalignment, also impair the use of configural information, further suggesting that upright face recognition depends on the encoding of spatial structure rather than just featural content.

Within the Modular Serial-Parallel Network (MSPN) framework, this theory can be tested by analyzing how spatial properties influence the structure of memory representations. Specifically, if configural processing is a core mechanism, manipulations of spatial relationships should systematically alter both the mean and variance parameters of memory representations, reflecting how spatial configurations affect facial encoding. The key MSPN prediction is that different spatial configurations (e.g., varying distances between features) should correspond to distinct mean and variance values. This would indicate that configural properties are explicitly encoded in memory rather than being merely an emergent consequence of feature integration..

div.head: Conversely, falsification of the configural processing account would occur if spatial
div.p: properties of facial features do not systematically modulate memory mean and variance, suggesting that face perception operates primarily at a featural level rather than encoding explicit configural relationships. In this case, MSPN would fail to detect distinct representational differences (in mean or variance) between spatially altered and unaltered faces, undermining the claim that configural information is independently represented in memory.

div.head: Interactive Configural Processing Theory: The Interactive Configural Processing
div.p: Theory (Maurer, Le Grand, & Mondloch, 2002) extends configural processing accounts by proposing that face perception integrates multiple levels of configural information, building upon Diamond and Carey's (1986) model. This theory suggests that face processing involves the integration of all facial features and their spatial relations into a single perceptual representation, rather than treating features as isolated units. It differentiates between three primary levels of configural processing: first-order relational processing, which enables recognition of a stimulus as a face due to its basic structural arrangement (e.g., two eyes above a nose and mouth); holistic processing, which integrates facial features into a unified percept, making it difficult to selectively attend to individual components; and second-order relational processing, which encodes subtle spatial variations among features, allowing for the discrimination of individual faces. While this theory provides a broad conceptual framework, it does not specify a systematic mechanism explaining how these different levels interact. A major limitation is the lack of a formal decision structure, making it unclear when and how different processing levels are engaged during face recognition. This reduces its falsifiability, as it does not generate specific predictions about when face perception relies on featural, holistic, or configural processing strategies.

The Modular Serial-Parallel Network (MSPN) provides a quantitative method for evaluating whether face perception dynamically transitions between these processing levels or consistently relies on a single interactive process. Within MSPN, the Interactive Configural Processing Theory can be tested by examining whether configural integration occurs through interactive processing mechanisms and whether task-dependent feature interactivity emerges. Specifically, MSPN predicts that in the composite face task, where participants must attend to one part of the face while ignoring the other, misaligned faces should exhibit independent processing (pcross = 0), while upright aligned faces should exhibit significant feature interactivity (pcross > 0). Additionally, if face inversion disrupts configural encoding, MSPN should reveal a reduction in feature interactivity (pcross > 0 with upright faces but decreased or absent with inverted faces). If interactive processing is central to holistic perception, inversion should lead to decreased, but not eliminated, feature interactivity (pcross > 0 with inversion), reflecting a partial breakdown of configural integration rather than a shift to purely featural processing.

Conversely, falsification of the Interactive Configural Processing Theory would occur if face processing does not exhibit task-dependent modulations of feature interactivity. Specifically, MSPN would fail to support the theory if misalignment conditions still showed interactivity (pcross > 0 in misaligned faces), suggesting that spatial alignment is not necessary for configural processing. Similarly, if face inversion does not lead to changes in feature interactivity (pcross remains the same across upright and inverted faces), it would suggest that configural processing is not fundamentally disrupted by inversion, contradicting one of the core assumptions of the theory.

Additionally, a strong falsification criterion would be if face recognition relies primarily on serial processing with self-termination (pmod = 0), meaning that decisions can be reached without integrating configural relationships.

div.head: Interactive Processing Models:
div.p: Interactive processing models (Fifić & Townsend, 2010) propose that holistic face effects arise from graded interactivity between facial features, rather than from a rigid face template. These models suggest that evidence accumulation across different facial features can range from completely independent processing (pcross = 0) to fully interactive, coactive processing (pcross = 1). The coactive processing framework suggests that face perception benefits from facilitatory parallel cross-talk between feature-processing channels, meaning that when face parts interact, the exchange of information aids identification by increasing the efficiency of evidence accumulation. This interaction occurs at different levels of integration, allowing graded holistic effects rather than an all-or-nothing template-driven process (Eidels et al., 2011).

Interactive facilitatory cross-talk between facial features has itself been posited as a theoretical definition of holistic processing . According to this approach, holistic face perception emerges from graded interactivity between facial features rather than being dependent exclusively on fixed configural representations. MSPN explicitly embodies this process-based perspective by allowing varying degrees of interactive information exchange across parallel channels. At lower levels of interaction (0 < pcross < 1), MSPN models partial interactivity between feature-specific channels, reflecting a continuum of holistic processing rather than a strictly categorical distinction between independent and integrated processing. When pcross = 0, face features are processed independently without inter-channel influence, indicating purely analytic processing. In contrast, at maximal interactivity (pcross = 1), MSPN describes fully coactive processing, in which information from separate feature channels merges completely, effectively simulating the effects of a holistic face template.

Importantly, coactivity can also be defined at the representational level, where a face is treated as a single entity, processed within one unified channel, implying complete integration at the stage of memory representation, prior to evidence accumulation (e.g. Townsend & Nozawa, 1995;Fifić, Little, & Nosofsky, 2010). This definition suggests that all feature integration and information pooling occur before any evidence accumulation or decision-making begins. Such a representation-based coactive model contrasts with MSPN's primary definition, which emphasizes process-based parallel interactive facilitation (Eidels et al., 2011). Despite conceptual differences, both process-based interactive models and representation-based coactive models generally yield similar empirical predictions for holistic processing effects (but see Howard et al., 2017, for potential dissociations).
MSPN thus distinguishes between these two interpretations by explicitly manipulating interactivity parameters within the evidence accumulation process.

div.head: Overlearned Attention Hypothesis:
div.p: The overlearned attention hypothesis (Chua, Richler, & Gauthier, 2014 challenges the notion that holistic effects arise from inherent, face-specific mechanisms, instead proposing that they stem from learned attentional biases. According to this view, holistic face processing is not an innate property of the visual system but rather a perceptual strategy that develops through experience and expertise in recognizing upright faces. Unlike theories that posit automatic, mandatory holistic integration, the overlearned attention hypothesis suggests that face perception relies on an attentional strategy that prioritizes whole-face processing due to its learned efficiency (Chua & Gauthier, 2016). However, this strategy is not obligatory; individual face parts remain available for independent processing, but over time, expertise makes attentional allocation less flexible and more biased toward holistic strategies (Richler et al., 2011a(Richler et al., , 2011bWong & Gauthier, 2010).

Empirical evidence supporting this theory comes from findings demonstrating that holistic effects can be learned and unlearned. The composite face task has been particularly useful in testing this hypothesis. Chua et al. (2015) showed that the composite face task interaction effect-often taken as evidence of holistic processingcan be trained to emerge with non-face objects. That is, if participants develop expertise with a novel stimulus class, they begin to process those stimuli holistically, similar to how faces are processed. Conversely, by manipulating face stimuli to disrupt their diagnostic value in a pre-task classification phase, the holistic effect can be eliminated for upright aligned faces (Chua et al., 2014). These findings suggest that holistic processing is a consequence of learned attentional strategies rather than an innate property of face perception. Learning to disregard non-diagnostic face regions reduces reliance on holistic strategies, demonstrating that the effect is not intrinsic to face perception itself but rather a byproduct of experience and expertise.

This attentional expertise hypothesis contrasts with strong holistic processing accounts, which assume that face perception innately requires the integration of all features into a single, unitary representation (Carey, 1992;Diamond & Carey, 1986;Gauthier & Tarr, 1997;Meadows, 1974). If holistic face perception were truly automatic, it should be resistant to learning-based modifications, yet the ability to both induce and eliminate holistic effects in experimental settings suggests that attentional biases, rather than face-specific mechanisms, drive these effects (Gauthier, Skudlarski, Gore, & Anderson, 2000;Grill-Spector et al., 2004;Xu, 2005).

One of the issues with the testability of the Overlearned Attentional Theory is that the so-called "holistic effects" can be attributed to several possible mechanisms, making it difficult to isolate a definitive explanation. For example, Chua et al. (2014) highlight this challenge: "Although our current data cannot speak to whether failures of selective attention to diagnostic composites occurred because of attention weights assigned to diagnostic parts, or from facilitated grouping of parts that were automatically attended, both of these explanations are consistent with our general hypothesis that learned attention to diagnostic parts drives holistic processing of faces."

This core ambiguity is that the observed holistic effects could stem from increased attentional weighting to specific facial features or from a facilitated perceptual grouping process that enhances holistic perception. These two mechanisms-attentional prioritization vs. grouping-are theoretically distinct according to the Modular Serial-Parallel Network (MSPN) theory and represent different levels of holistic processing.

The first account, in terms of MSPN, focuses on enhancing memory processes for particular facial features. If holistic effects stem from learned attentional strategies, then MSPN should reveal increasing drift rates and decreasing memory variance with expertise, reflecting greater efficiency and stability in facial representations over time.
These effects would be evident as changes in the drift rate of memory representations and their variance.

However, the second account aligns more closely with the Parallel Interactive Processing approach (Fific & Townsend, 2010, which assumes that holistic effects in facial recognition tasks (e.g., composite face paradigms) emerge due to increased facilitation between face parts. In MSPN terms, this would manifest as changes in the pcross parameter, indicating stronger perceptual integration between facial features.

In short, the Overlearned Attentional Theory (Chua, Richler, & Gauthier, 2014) may not be fully defined regarding how selective attention to facial parts occurs. This is where MSPN provides a critical advantage, as its framework allows for a precise examination of the presence or absence of violations of selective influence-a key distinction that can only be observed under a serial self-terminating processing framework. Within the MSPN model, this would require clear-cut attentional separation of facial parts, something that holistic effects should disrupt if interactive processing mechanisms are at play. In addition, MSPN allows for distinguishing the between the type of failure of the selective attention, that could result in the so-called observed holistic effect, that is whether it is simply the result of the increasing memory weights of the attended facial parts, and/or it is the results of cross facilitation between facial parts. Thus, distinguishing between these competing accounts requires empirical tests that manipulate attentional weighting and perceptual grouping separately, while leveraging MSPN's parameters (drift rate, variance, pcross) to detect systematic changes in processing dynamics.

div.head: Failure of Selective Attention Hypothesis:
div.p: The failure of selective attention is not a theoretical framework but rather an empirical construct used to characterize the inability to selectively process individual facial features without interference from irrelevant face parts (for an overview see . Although frequently cited as evidence of holistic face perception, it is not a singular phenomenon but rather a broad category of effects that can emerge through different mechanisms.

Various experimental paradigms have been used to operationalize this construct, with the composite face task serving as a primary method. This task demonstrates that observers struggle to ignore irrelevant facial information when making feature-based judgments, leading to interference effects that suggest faces are not perceived as independent features but as integrated wholes. Similarly, the Garner interference task (Garner, 1974) provides additional evidence that facial dimensions are difficult to process independently, as variations in irrelevant dimensions often disrupt task performance. The fact that these tasks capture the failure of selective attention in different ways raises the question of whether holistic face processing is a consequence of perceptual integration, attentional constraints, or decision-level interactions.

Richler & Gauthier (2014) outline multiple possible mechanisms underlying the failure of selective attention, emphasizing that holistic face perception may arise due to distinct cognitive and perceptual processes rather than a single unified effect. One proposed mechanism is perceptual-level integration, in which facial features are automatically bound together in early visual processing, making it difficult to isolate individual features . Another account suggests that attentional constraints play a role, with expertise-driven biases prioritizing whole-face representations, making selective processing effortful (Wong & Gauthier, 2010).

Finally, decision-level interference provides an alternative explanation, in which responses to one feature are influenced by congruency effects from irrelevant features, leading to systematic disruptions in accuracy and response times. These different mechanisms indicate that holistic face effects may not stem from a single cognitive process but rather from multiple interacting sources of interference.

The diversity of these potential mechanisms presents a challenge for holistic processing theories, as different experimental paradigms may be capturing distinct cognitive effects rather than a single cohesive process. Given this complexity, it is necessary to employ rigorous computational methods that can differentiate between these underlying mechanisms. The Modular Serial-Parallel Network (MSPN) offers a powerful framework for testing whether holistic face perception results from genuine feature integration or from attentional and decision-level limitations. MSPN allows for a direct assessment of whether interference effects stem from processing constraints, attentional biases, or response-based congruency effects by distinguishing between serial, parallel, and interactive processing architectures.

If holistic effects arise purely due to attentional limitations, MSPN should reveal strong evidence for serial processing (pmod = 0) and feature independence (pcross = 0), indicating that face perception is not truly holistic but rather that selective attention is constrained by experience-driven biases. This would support the idea that faces are not necessarily processed as wholes but rather that individual features cannot be selectively ignored due to learned attentional strategies or decision-level interference.

div.head: Walkthrough of a two-feature face categorization study
div.p: In this section, we provide a step-by-step account of how MSPN operates in a binary decision task (computational details are presented in Appendix A). We assume an experiment in which an observer must learn to categorize faces with respect to two second-order facial features: eye-to-eye separation and lips-to-nose separation (see e.g., Fifić, 2006;Fifić & Townsend, 2010;Yang, Fific, Chang et al., 2018). From these two dimensions, we create a set of faces such that each face varies on the two properties but in different combinations. Assume that 4 featural values are selected for each dimension; when orthogonally combined, this produces a 4 ×4 stimulus space (see Figure 1) .

Assume the goal is to that the binary task involves learning to perceptually recognize two groups of faces, Group A and Group B, as indicated in Figure 1 ( Figure 1; dotted lines in the face matrix), such that subjects would learn to accurately make a classification decision and respond Category B either when the separation of two eyes or the separation between lips and nose of the test face was narrower than that of the reference face {4, 4}, and otherwise, respond Category A. During the initial phase of the task, a participant would learn the values of the facial features and develop a featural representation for each dimension.

When a test face is presented, MSPN assumes that it is decomposed into featural representations activated in memory. For example, when test face {7,5} is displayed (Figure 1, circled face), the activated featural representations are eye-to-eye separation {7} and lips-to-nose separation {5}. The cognitive system determines whether the activated features belong to category A or B by sampling evidence from both sources.

The sampling process is a stochastic process and occurs in small steps over time via a random walk. At each step, sampled evidence is classified as either category A or B evidence by comparing the sampled featural dimensional value to the decision criteria.

We assume that the decision criteria is approximately {4, 4}, the midpoint on both dimensions. The retrieved value of the eye-to-eye separation and lips-to-nose separation might be {6.37, 3.13} (e.g., a random draw from a normal distribution centered at {7, 5}. In this case one source of evidence would be classified as belonging to category A: {6.37 > 4}, and the other as belonging to category B: {3.13 < 4}. This evidence drives the two random walks counters, each accumulating evidence from a single feature. The first RW increases one step toward the A bound; the second increases one step toward 3 There are several reasons for choosing this particular design. First, application of the orthogonal manipulation of featural properties (4 × 4) leads to a factorial design, which can be used to correctly identify the underlying mechanistic structure of the cognitive processes involved (e.g., serial versus parallel processing). The foundation of this idea is demonstrated in work of the Systems Factorial Technology (Townsend & Nozawa, 1995;Fific & Little, 2017), which is a methodological suite of tools designed to improve identification of underlying processing orders, while avoiding model mimicry. Second, the full factorial design, allows for testing properties of using different logical rule combinations which result in different predictions for the conjunctive and disjunctive rule categories (Fifić et al., 2010;Little, Eidels, Fifić & Wang, 2015;. Third, this stimulus design defines three regions of the stimulus configuration set (more details in the method section). Under task specifications, these regions incur different processing mechanisms thus forcing different outcome behavior of different models, which can improve identification of model's properties. the B bound. Before continuing, the system tests whether one of the two counters reached either decision bound. If the B boundary is reached then the system stops and a B response is generated. This is called the "OR" rule of information integration or sometimes referred to as the self-terminating rule. If both counters reach the A boundary, then the system would stop too and trigger the A category response. Given that both featural sources match the category membership, this rule was defined as the "AND" rule or sometimes referred to as exhaustive stopping rule. The system continues gathering evidence if it is unable to make a final decision. The evidence sampling process is random, so the next set of values collected could be {7.12, 5.13}, which would both indicate category A membership.

The accumulation of evidence for both features can be conducted in a serial or in parallel fashion (Figure 1 on the right). If the system uses a serial module, then the two random walks would be engaged in sequential order; that is, evidence sampling would occur on one feature (e.g., eye-to-eye separation) first. The order of serial completion is governed by the parameter pser, representing the probability that, on each individual trial, the dimensions are processed in the order lips-to-nose -then-eyes-to-eyes (rather than eyes-to-eyes then-lips-to-nose, see Appendix A). Depending on the final classification decision (A or B), the RW will terminate on finding that the first feature is B (following the "OR" rule) or continue with the second feature following classification as A (following the "AND" rule). If the second processed feature is classified as B then the system would respond B. Otherwise, the final response would be A. If processing is parallel, both random walks operate at the same time. The same logic is used to determine the final response based on the outcomes of each RW.

If the parallel processing module is engaged, then the system can further engage the interactive mechanism. In the computational model, the interaction is determined by the amount of cross-talk, pcross, between the featural random walks (Appendix A).

The interactivity is modulated by the opening of the communication gate between the two random walks. If the gate is fully open (pcross=1), the evidence in both channels is summed in each channel creating a correlated set of random walks. In the illustrative example, if the evidence sample is {7.12, 5.13}, each random walk will add one unit of evidence toward the A boundary; however, given that the gate is open, this evidence is exchanged and added to both evidence counts. Consequently, sampling congruent evidence rapidly leads to accumulation toward a boundary leading to faster decisions (see the superimposed random walks in Figure 1, right the Parallel Interactive module).

By contrast, if the sampled evidence is {6.37, 3.13} (i.e., a step toward A in the first RW and a step toward B in the second), the random walks exchange incongruent evidence. When incongruent evidence is exchanged, the random walk that stepped toward A would receive unit evidence to step down toward B resulting in sedentary state after sampling evidence. Sampling incongruent evidence slows processing. Under conditions where mainly congruent evidence is exchanged the two random walks create a high-level integral representation that could be defined as extreme holistic encoding.

If the gate is closed (pcross = 0; i.e., pure independent channel processing), this prevents the exchange of evidence and results in access to individual facial features. If the gate is partially open (0 < pcross < 1), some evidence exchange between two random walks is allowed which results in correlations of different magnitudes between two featural detectors.

In MSPN, modularity is controlled through a mechanism that allows the system to operate in either a serial or parallel module. The switch between modules from trial to trial is controlled by the parameter pmod. This adaptive behavior enables the system to process features either sequentially or in parallel, affecting the overall behavior across multiple trials. Such dynamics ensure that the system's output is a mix of responses from the two modules, enhancing the cognitive system's capability to exhibit more naturalistic behavior in its organizational processes. This is akin to how natural cognitive systems might operate, allowing for a flexible and adaptive response pattern that aligns with the varying demands of environmental stimuli.

A related approach, the Multiattribute Dynamic Decision (MADD) model, also employs modularity by dividing cognitive processes into modules capable of serial or parallel operation (Diederich, 1997(Diederich, , 2024Diederich & Oswald, 2016) One of the critical questions researchers explore when combining several cognitive models within the common MSPN framework is whether the integration affects the identifiability of these nested models. To address this concern, we conducted a validation procedure to assess whether the nested models maintain their distinctiveness and identifiability amidst the amalgamation (please see Appendix B).
These tests consistently demonstrate strong model discriminability and identifiability, addressing any potential concerns of model mimicking or confusion.

The validation procedure provides robust evidence that the combined cognitive models retain their individual characteristics and can be effectively differentiated within the overarching MSPN framework. This reassures us that our approach of unifying these models under MSPN does not compromise their integrity or hinder their distinct identification.

div.head: MSPN as an umbrella for process analysis or as an exploratory tool
div.p: Note that MSPN, as an umbrella framework, does not prescribe specific mechanisms or details for individual face perceptual processes. Instead, MSPN can be used as a starting point to develop more detailed and specific questions about processing.

MSPN can also serve as a validation/falsification tool for critical assumptions, providing evidence for serial or parallel processes in computational face perception networks or testing specific models of evidence accumulation modules used (continuous or discrete time models) and the properties of memory representations underlying them.

In the subsequent section, we apply MSPN framework as an exploratory tool, specifically focusing on its utility in testing holistic analytic assumptions and providing validation tests for major facial paradigms. Two prominent examples, namely the composite face and the part-to-whole paradigm, will be examined using the MSPN framework.

We will also introduce and elucidate how MSPN can serve as a theoretical tool in the realm of categorization perceptual tasks, particularly addressing the phenomenon of the other-race effect. This section will demonstrate the application of MSPN in examining cognitive processes related to the other-race effect. By doing so, we aim to showcase the versatility of MSPN as a theoretical framework for understanding and analyzing complex perceptual tasks within the domain of face perception, specifically emphasizing its relevance in the context of the other-race effect.

div.head: Applying MSPN to the composite face paradigm
div.p: The composite task has become a standard paradigm in face processing research, applied to various areas such as tracking face recognition development, studying abnormal face recognition development, and evaluating computational models (Cassia et al., 2009;Le Grand et al., 2006;Dailey & Cottrell, 1999). Holistic processing is inferred from a Congruency × Alignment interaction on sensitivity (d', Richler, Cheung, & Gauthier, 2011a,2011b. MSPN offers a comprehensive solution to address various limitations in the context of the composite face paradigm and to provide validation/falsification tool, with which one can explore assumptions underlying face processing:

1. Joint Analysis of RT and Accuracy: In the traditional approach to testing facial perception, researchers typically analyze either only one measure or, less commonly, both measures in their studies. However, these are typically analyzed separately, and the results are compared for converging validity properties. MSPN's ability to make joint predictions for both reaction time (RT) and accuracy supports the validation of its inferences regarding the specific underlying processes being investigated. The joint analysis allows for explaining intricate relationships between RTs and accuracies, such as a trade-off between these two measures, within the same theoretical framework.

2. Avoiding Tradeoffs: Separate random walks, associated with different facial features, are engaged in sampling evidence from feature representations. The engagement of random walks' response criteria A and B allows the model to create a variety of response outcomes, including tradeoffs, thus incorporating these as the verifiable theoretical constructs. Thus, the model can dynamically adjust its processing mode based on the requirements of the task and participant strategies.

Modular Organization: MSPN's modular structure allows for both serial and parallel processing, enabling a probabilistic engagement of these modules. This allows MSPN to flexibly switch between analytic and holistic encoding in perceptual operations, accommodating the joint analysis of both reaction times (RTs) and accuracy.

Parameters like pmod control the likelihood of using the serial or parallel module, . Critics have pointed out that the partial composite face design, when compared to the complete composite face design, is less valid due to confounds from decisional bias (Richler Gauthier, Wenger, Palmeri 2008;. However, counterarguments (Rossion, 2013;Rezlescu et al., 2017) suggest that the complete design is is not convincingly strong and lacks construct validity (Rossion, 2013). Note: Stimuli are arranged across two critical dimensions, shown here only for the aligned conditions (the misaligned condition has the same stimulus configuration). The upper face half is the "target", and the bottom face half is "irrelevant". The running assumption is that the irrelevant part can also influence making final perception decision, and depending on the serial or parallel module used can differently contribute to response behavior. The green lines indicate the decision bounds that are used to separate each stimulus dimension into response regions. The dataset used in the MSPN analysis is from the Gao et al. (2011). The study used the complete composite-face paradigm , where participants first matched Navon stimuli at either the global or local level before attempting to match the top halves of composite faces. 4

The same/different decision is influenced from two sources. The first source is the target feature, in this case the upper facial section. If the target feature is the sole basis of decision making, then we term this a single-dimensional model. The second source is the irrelevant bottom section of the face. We assume a stimulus configuration that represents the facial feature space. This configuration operates in an orthogonal dimension space with two dimensions associated with each of the top and bottom facial sections. The top and bottom sections can either be the "same" or "different" across the study/test pairs (see Figure 3).

We postulate that the presentation of the same/different congruent and incongruent conditions engage the modular processing system outlined by MSPN allowing for a flexible switch between analytic and holistic encoding in perceptual operations. Several hypotheses are proposed based on the MSPN framework:

(1) Although the bottom section of the face does not help participants respond in the composite face task, we assume that when faces are aligned, the bottom face half influence performance through some degree of holistic processing or failure of selective attention. In terms of MSPN, by allowing the "irrelevant" non-target dimension to influence perceptual decision-making, we should find better model performance compared to the single-dimension model. This should allow the model to predict errors observed in the composite face task and provides a processing-based instantiation of a failure of selective attention.

(2) We expect that misaligning the face halves results in more analytic processing than aligning the faces. We predict that the best-fitting model in the aligned condition will demonstrate a prevalence for holistic encoding, revealed in the MSPN as an increase in the pcross parameter. By contrast, the misaligned conditions should show a tendency toward analytic encoding with a value of the pmod parameter closer to 0 and the absence of parallel processing and process facilitations. Model fitting details: The computational models' properties are described in the Appendix C. We fitted the models to the mean RTs and response accuracies, aggregated across subjects, as reported in Gao et al. (2011). The model fits are reported in Table 2, separately for the aligned and misaligned face conditions. The best fitting parameter values across models are reported in Table 3. The critical statistics used to infer holistic processing, the Congruency × Alignment interaction values, are reported in Table 4. For comparison in Figure 4 we displayed the Congruency × Alignment interaction values as observed in the Gao et al. (2011) vs the best model fit provided by MSPN. The models demonstrated strong alignment with the aggregated subjects' data. Unsurprisingly, as model complexity increased, so did the fit. As higher-level hierarchical representations are engaged, there is a better correspondence between the model and the data. In every instance, the full MSPN yielded the most accurate fits to the data compared to all other models 5 .

First, we observe that incorporating so-called "irrelevant" or non-target dimension in perceptual decision-making results in improvements compared to the singledimension model (Table 2). This finding lends support to the notion that the composite effects partly arise from attending to irrelevant dimensions (or failure to suppress attention to irrelevant dimensions). This is further validated by the finding that the single-dimension model demonstrates a much better fit to the data in the misaligned condition than in the aligned condition. Second, in the aligned condition, model fit consistently improves when combining serial and parallel models (Table 2: It is noteworthy that MSPN provides a high resolution of the underlying perceptual and cognitive processes, offering insights that cannot be observed using other methodologies in the composite face task. For instance, Cheng et al. (2018Cheng et al. ( , 2025 argued in favor of a mixture of serial and parallel processing of composite face but did not directly model the composite face task, instead relying on fitting a categorization task (like our Figure 1) and arguing for a generalization across task types.

Also, the Congruency × Alignment interaction values estimated from the model fits provide important clues to understand the convergent properties of the MSPN properties achieve the observed results. Consequently, insights from MSPN can be used to validate or falsify proposed models in facial perception.

( Table 4). The results show that two models -the single dimension and the parallel model -showed zero interaction contrast values, indicating an inability to fit the observed data and an absence of holistic encoding. All other models showed some positive Congruency × Alignment interaction. This is expected for the mixed-serial parallel model (serial/parallel in Table 2, 3 and 4), the interactive parallel model, and MSPN. Interestingly, the serial model was also able to generate the interaction albeit of a small magnitude; this is unexpected given the assumption of additivity typically associated with serial processing (Sternberg, 1969). However, a mixed order in the sequence of processing two facial features combined with significant error responses introduces the possibility of non-additive effects. (e.g., Chua et al., 2015Chua et al., , 2016 can be instantiated in MSPN. Moreover, decision bound placement allows several response outcomes. In the Appendix D, we illustrate how a single MSPN parameter, decision bound placement (Dx), operating on the "target" feature, can contribute to significant Congruency × Alignment interactions across aligned and misaligned conditions, that qualitatively matches those observed in other studies. In the serial model, the decisional component on the "relevant" facial feature can produce the hallmark of holistic processing although the model is strongly analytic.

In essence, the conclusion is that the Congruency × Alignment interaction is not a helpful statistic for identifying the specific combination of information processing characteristics that underlie performance. MSPN allows us to move beyond simplistic interaction analyses; this allows for a comprehensive understanding of the complex interplay between different cognitive processes involved in face perception.

div.head: Applying MSPN to the part-to-whole paradigm
div.p: In the part/whole task (Tanaka & Sengco, 1997), participants initially study a whole face and then are tested on their memory of individual parts presented both in isolation and within the context of the whole face. Studies employing the part/whole task consistently demonstrate that recognition of individual parts is more accurate when tested in the whole-face condition compared to in isolation, providing empirical support Hierarchical Face Representations for a holistic perspective where alterations in the typical viewing configuration interfere with recognition. Importantly, this advantage is specific to normal, intact, upright faces and is not observed for inverted or scrambled faces or non-face objects. A key result is the sequence of correct recognition rates, P(c), is ordered across different conditions: Like the composite face interaction, the specific processes underlying the order of accuracy across conditions is not revealed by this ordering. Fific and Townsend (2010) applied Systems Factorial Technology to suggests that the observed sequence, P(c) isolated parts < P(c) old configuration, could be explained by a non-holistic mechanism (Fific & Townsend, 2010). For instance, the old configuration condition contains more features congruent with the target face than the isolated parts condition. The addition of congruent features might allow for a redundant target effect (RTE; Raab, 1962;Miller, 1982), which can be explained through parallel processing (i.e., statistical facilitation; Miller, 1982), which is only weakly holistic if the channels are independent according to Townsend and Wenger's spectrum (Townsend & Wenger, 2004;Wenger & Townsend, 2001). .
The challenge for a parallel processing explanation is the "new configuration" condition also leads to improved accuracy compared to the isolated parts condition.

Novel configurations incorporate incongruent facial features (those not belonging to Joe) that could obstruct the recognition of the face stimuli containing the target features (Joe's face). Redundant feature processing in the new configuration condition could reduce response accuracy due to the introduction of incongruent features. Alternatively, an independent parallel model might not be affected by incongruent conflicting information (Little et al., 2015 but could still benefit from some redundancy due to configural information in the new configuration condition. In the original paper, all three conditions were intermixed within a single block of trials (Tanaka & Sengco, 1997) making it improbable that different processing strategies are employed across conditions.

When the target feature is embedded in either a new or old configuration, target and non-target features could be processed sequentially or in parallel and may involve interactions or operate independently, as depicted in Figure 5 (bottom).

For a strictly serial process, it is plausible that the perceptual analysis begins with the "non-target" facial feature, which may or may not belong to our target face, Joe. If this non-target feature is identified, correctly or incorrectly, as belonging to Joe, the system may self-terminate even though the target feature has not been analyzed. This could allow a serial process to predict the pattern of P(c)isolated parts < P(c)new configuration < P(c)old configuration.

As in our application to the composite face task, we assume a specific configuration representing the facial feature space. This configuration operates on an orthogonal dimension space with two dimensions associated with each of the target feature and the facial context, varying between "same" (i.e., belongs to Joe) or "different." (i.e., doesn't belong to Joe, see Figure 5).
