Note the top panel corresponds to the isolated parts condition, where only the target feature is presented without any facial context; the bottom panel represents the stimulus configuration where the target feature is presented along with facial context, either belonging to Joe (Old Configuration) or not (New Configuration). The separation of the panels is solely for the sake of clarity in presentation, and it is assumed that both configurations initiate the same memory system for retrieval of activated facial feature representation. The middle/smaller circle letter indicates the target feature A=Joe, and B=not Joe. A and B condition trials were mixed within a block. The difference between diagrams in A and B is that in the isolated part condition, only a single feature is presented so, it is assumed that it can only give a rise to one memory representation for presented facial feature, so that the only one decision bound was used in the model. The other two conditions shown in B, would display two parts the target feature location small circle A and B and the facial context part (large circle A and B). It is assumed that these two conditions will give a rise to two activated mental representations that could be assessed, and the two decision bounds were used accordingly. The

div.head: Dy Dx
div.p: We make the following hypotheses:

1. Non-holistic approaches (i.e., serial processing) can predict the observed pattern of accuracy (P(c)isolated parts < P(c)new configuration < P(c)old configuration). To determine this, we use MSPN to evaluate (a) whether processing is more serial or more parallel and (b) whether there is any process interactivity in the parallel module.

2. We anticipate that the degree of holism, as identified by the transition from serial to parallel processing and by augmenting the level of facial featural interactions, will progressively increase across different stimulus types, including houses, inverted and upright faces.

div.head: Model fitting
div.p: The computational models' properties are described in Appendix E. We fit three models to the mean response accuracies, aggregated across subjects, as reported in Tanaka and Sengco (1997). The model fits are reported in Table 5, separately for the Eyes, Nose, and Mouth Features shown in Isolation, in a New Configuration, and in the Old Configuration, all in the upright faces (as shown in Experiment 1 of Tanaka et al., 1997).

The best-fitting parameter values across models are reported in Appendix E. Tanaka and Sengco (1997). The model predictions matched the mean response accuracies for the parallel and parallel interactive models, with only slight variations in the second decimal for the serial model. The near-identical fit between the serial and parallel modules suggest that the observed effects cannot differentiate separate perceptual processes, rendering the use of the full MSPN unnecessary.

We additionally compared the three models with the second dataset provided in Experiment 2 in Tanaka & Sengco (1997), this time involving the recognition accuracies for Eyes, Nose, and Mouth Features in Upright and Inverted Faces shown in Isolation, New Configuration, and in Old Configuration (see Table 5). All the models provided an excellent match to the observed data for the upright faces. The models produced excellent fits to the inverted faces condition except for the failure of the serial model in the Mouth condition. Finally, we fit the models to Tanaka and Sengco's Experiment 3 which used houses as stimuli. All models fit the data very well, with only a few discrepancies between the observed and fitted data (see Table 5).

We can draw several conclusions: First, non-holistic approaches nested within MSPN accurately capture the observed pattern of ordered effects, where facial feature recognition accuracy follows the sequence P(c)isolated parts < P(c)new configuration < P(c)old configuration. The near-identical results when fitting the serial and parallel modules suggests that the observed effects alone cannot distinguish between separate perceptual processes. Additionally, MSPN's ability to fit non-holistic stimuli, such as inverted faces and houses, indicates that all stimuli in this experiment can be accounted for by highly analytic processing. These findings are commensurate with Fific & Townsend (2010) who suggested that the ordering of correct response recognition may not be useful to differentiate complex of information-processing systems.
We note that our simulation did not include all dependent variables (e.g., accuracy

for "different" trials or RT) as these were not reported in the original study (Tanaka & Sengco, 1997). Incorporating these measures could further constrain MSPN's predictions leading to improved model identification.

div.head: Experiment Other race-face paradigm
div.p: In the next application, we use MSPN to explore information processing in the perception of configural facial features in other-and same-race faces. The other-race effect refers to the difficulty of discriminating between faces from ethnic and racial groups other than one's own. From the perspective of the analytic vs holistic encoding, the other-race effect is seen as a difficulty in engaging holistic encoding for other race faces (Tanaka, Kiefer, & Bukach, 2004;Rhodes, Hayward & Winkler, 2006;Michel, Corneille, & Rossion, 2007;Hancock & Rhodes, 2008;Bukach, et al., 2012;Zhao, Hayward, & Bülthoff, 2014). Other-race faces are analytically encoded and are therefore more prone to recognition errors due to a slow feature-by-feature comparison (Michel, Caldara, & Rossion, 2006;Tanaka, Kiefer, & Bukach, 2004;Yang, Fific, Chang, & Little, 2018). In contrast, same-race faces are holistically encoded, which

gives rise to fast perceptual detections that are less error prone. Recent research further suggests that while both same-race and other-race faces demonstrate a congruency × alignment interaction in the complete composite design, but with same race faces encoded and processed more efficiently (though there are some differences between
Caucasian and Asian participants that could reflect social categorization or cultural tendencies; Harrison, Gauthier, Hayward, & Richler, 2014).

In the current study, we manipulate configural facial features across different race faces by testing a group of Caucasian participants (form the US) and a group of Asian participants (from Taiwan). Configural features (also termed second-order relations;

Maurer, Le Grand, & Mondloch, 2002) refer to coding of spatial relations between facial features. The canonical positions of facial features (eyes are above nose and nose above mouth) are defined as the first-order relations. The second-order relations are spatial variations within these first-order relations (Diamond & Carey, 1986;Maurer, Le Grand, & Mondloch, 2002). Second-order relations are important for perceptual discrimination of faces and can provide important clues to face identification (Fifić & Townsend, 2010;Yang, Fific, Chang, & Little, 2018). In addition to the first-and second-order relational features, our facial perception relies on recognition of particular facial properties, such as the nose, eyes, lips, or skin texture. For the purpose of detecting the holistic vs analytic encoding properties across races, we will limit the domain of our exploration to only the second-order relations.

The use of second-order features should also help validate MSPN. Previous studies using second-order facial features demonstrated holistic signatures in a face categorization task implementing comparison of parts versus wholes (Fifić & Townsend, 2010). This study found evidence for coactivity using Systems Factorial

Technology (Townsend & Nozawa, 1995) implying that facial features were pooled together indicative of extreme parallel facilitation, as described in Figure (bottom right). Identification of coactivity suggests strong holistic encoding (Fifić & Townsend, 2010). More importantly for the present paper, it was also observed that different processing architectures (serial, parallel, coactive) were employed across different facial conditions. For example, when the contextual facial features changed, thus affecting the overall facial configuration, there was more reliance on analytic processing than on holistic processing. By contrast, Cheng and Little (2025) found no evidence of coactivity but instead found that second order face categorization was best explained by a mixture of serial and parallel processing, with more serial processing when faces were misaligned and more parallel processing when faces were aligned.

One question (Fifić & Townsend, 2010) was whether the other-race effect could show some differences in the types of processing from the processing of same-race faces. In a follow up study, Yang, Fifić, Chang, & Little . (2018) manipulated secondorder relational features across face race conditions. Using SFT (Townsend & Nozawa, 1995;, the authors showed the weak holistic encoding for the samerace faces and strong analytic encoding for the other-race faces. That is, same-race faces were processed in a parallel self-terminating fashion, and other-race faces were processed in a serial self-terminating fashion. These results further supported the idea of modularity of the underlying processing networks.

div.head: Expectations
div.p: Our primary goal is to analyze the perceptual and cognitive properties of facial perception. Our second goal is to compare the properties of the face perception of the two different races and their properties of the face perception of the other-and the samerace faces. Our participant groups are Eastern Asian (e.g., Taiwan) and Western

Caucasian (e.g., USA). These groups geographically reside within their native race culture and are consequently less exposed to faces of another race. Two sets of faces that are typical for the Asian and Caucasian cultures will be used in the classification task.

First, independently of the subject's race, we expect to observe mainly evidence for holistic encoding of faces; that is, subjects should show more prevalence of parallel then serial processing and more interdependent than independent processing (Wenger & Townsend, 2001). These properties will be evident from the model parameters, pmod and pcross, respectively. Note that the current approach does not require some form of holistic disruption of faces to test "holistic" level of processing unlike other methods (e.g., face inversion or misalignment). Consequently, MSPN can test holistic properties on natural variations in position of facial features, thus increasing the study's ecological validity.

Second, following a large body of evidence in the domain of face perception, we expect our results to support the other-race effect, that is more perceptual holism associated with a same-race face compared to an other-race face. Accordingly, we expect that the same-race faces will show more cross-talk interaction between facial features and/or more evidence for switching to parallel processing of facial features than the other-race faces. In contrast, it is expected that the other-race faces will demonstrate more facial feature independence and/or serial processing.

div.head: Apparatus
div.p: For the Taiwanese group, the experiment was conducted in a darkened room on a 2.40 GHz Intel Pentium IV processor running E-prime 1.1 (Schneider, Eschman, & Zuccolotto, 2002). The stimuli were presented on a 19-inch CRT monitor (CTX VL951T) with a refresh rate of 85 Hz and resolution of 1024×768. A chin-rest was used in order to prevent head movements. For the US group, the experiment was conducted in a darkened room on a 3.2 GHz Intel Core i5-4570 processor running E-prime 1.1
The stimuli were presented on a 24-inch LCD monitor (Dell U2412M) with a refresh rate of 59 Hz and resolution of 1024×768. A chin-rest was used in order to prevent head movements.

div.head: Design, Stimuli, and Procedure
div.p: Participants were required to perform two experiments tested with the own-race faces and other-race-faces, respectively. The test order of the two experiments was counterbalanced across participants. The face stimuli were the same as those used in Yang, Fific, Chang, & Little (2018); each face was 12° in height and 8° in width (see Figure 6). The Western Caucasian and Eastern Asian female faces were regarded as typical faces which were rated by another group of participants from the same subject pool (please see Yang, Fific, Chang, & Little 2018, supplementary materials for the rating results). Each experiment consisted of two phases: a psychophysical phase and formal test phase.

div.head: Psychophysical Phase
div.p: In the psychophysical phase, we asked the participants to perform a face classification task based on the comparison between the eye-to-eye separation or lipsto-nose separation of a reference face and the test face. We adopted the method of the method of constant stimuli to measure the psychometric function relating feature separation to classification accuracy. The psychometric functions were then used to select salience levels of the eye-to-eye separation and lips-to-nose separation for the following formal test phase. Specifically, there were seven levels for each feature. Only one facial feature was manipulated at a time; that is, when eye-to-eye separation was tested, the lips-to-nose separation of the test face (level 4) was kept the same as that of the reference face; on the other hand, when lips-to-nose separation was tested, the eyeto-eye separation of the test face (level 4) was kept the same as that of the reference face. The eye-to-eye separation was 32, 36, 40, 44, 48, 52, or 8, 10, 12, 14, 16, 18, or 20 pixels (level 1 to level 7) for Caucasian face. The reference face was defined as the stimulus with level 4 in both eye-to-eye separation and lips-to-nose separation (i.e., Asian face: eye-separation: 44 pixel; lipsto-nose separation: pixel; Caucasian face: eye-to-eye separation: 28 pixel; lips-tonose separation: pixel). Figure 6 shows the two second-order manipulations, separately for Eastern Asian face stimuli. In half of the trials, the test face was the same as the reference face whereas in the rest of trials, the test face and the reference were different in one of the second-order relational manipulations. Specifically, eye-to-eye separation contained seven levels and lips-to-nose separation also contained seven levels. Participants first performed a practice block of 70 trials. Participants then performed 10 blocks of 70 test trials. All the second-order manipulations were randomly intermixed within a block with equal presentation frequency. Across four sessions, which were conducted on different days, there were 200 trials per manipulation in total.

A psychometric function can then be obtained from the observed data and based on the results of the psychometric function, we can individually select the salience levels for the factorial manipulations in the formal experiment. The selection method is introduced as follows. First, for each individual subject, we plotted the probabilities of responding "Category B" as a function of eye-to-eye separation levels and lips-to-nose separation levels, respectively. The psychometric functions were monotonically Hierarchical Face Representations decreasing functions ranging from 1 to 0. Low accuracy (ACC) may result in incorrect SFT inferences regarding the processing characteristics (but see Little, Yang, Eidels & Townsend, 2022); thus, we used a criterion of ACC > 0.9 for the selection of high and low salience levels. Second, we plotted the correct RTs as a function of eye-to-eye separation levels and lips-to-nose separation levels, respectively. These functions were inverted U-shape functions, with the fastest RTs for both the narrowest (level 1) and widest level (level 7), which were obviously different from the reference stimulus level (level 4), and the slowest RT for the level closest to the reference stimulus level (level 4). We then combined both the ACC and RT information while keeping the accuracy higher than 0.9 (i.e., the first step) to derive the high and low salience levels for the narrowest and widest separation cases, respectively, via interpolation. This method would ensure that Category A and Category B were equally discriminable.

The high discriminability level (H) was defined as the stimulus level with approximately100% accuracy and similar RT for Category A and Category B. The low discriminability level (L) was defined as the stimulus level with approximately 90% accuracy and similar RT for Category A and Category B. Levels were calibrated separately for each individual subject. The stimulus levels were formally defined as discrete levels ranging from 1, 1.5, 2, …, to 7. Levels were rounded to the nearest .5.

div.head: Test Phase
div.p: On each trial, after presentation of a fixation point for 350 ms, a test face was presented centrally until a response was made. Participants were instructed to quickly and accurately make a classification decision and respond Category B ("Amy" for a Caucasian face or "美玲"for an Asian face) either when the separation of two eyes of the test face was narrower than that of the reference face or when the separation between lips and nose of the test face was narrower than that of the reference face, and to, otherwise, respond Category A ("Mary" for a Caucasian face or "淑芬" for an Asian face). The inter-trial interval was 500 ms.

In the formal test phase, the design was a 4 (eye-to-eye separation) × 4 (lips-tonose separation) factorial design. As a result, there were 16 stimuli grouped into four categories (Figure 1). (1) Redundant Category B: in this category, both eye-to-eye separation and lips-to-nose separation of the test face were narrower than those of the reference face;
(2) Single Category B with eye-to-eye separation narrower than the reference;

(3) Single Category B with lips-to-nose separation narrower than the reference; (4) Category A: both eye-to-eye separation and lips-to-nose separation of the test face were furtherer than those of the reference face.

The experimental procedure of the test phase was the same as the psychophysical phase. After a practice block of 40 trials, participants performed ten sessions of 800 trials, divided into ten blocks. All the trials were randomly intermixed within a block with equal presentation frequency. After the experiment, there were 500 trials for each condition.

div.head: Results and Discussion
div.p: Response time and accuracy analyses, the face categorization task

Conditionalized on each individual subject and stimulus, we removed RTs greater than 3 standard deviations above the mean and RTs less than 100 msec. This procedure led to removal of less than 1.8% of the trials from analysis.

The mean correct RTs and error rates for each face race, across all subjects averaged across all stimuli for the respective facial condition are reported in Table 8. In general, there is a substantial variability in both RTs and accuracy rates across subjects. Note: Participants c1-c5 are Caucasians, and a1-a5 are Asians. SE: standard error of mean; ORE=other-race effect; I-ORE=Inverse other-race effect; one-way ANOVA for the difference effect (df1=1 and df2>15000 depending on the number of correct responses in the analysis); *p < .05；**p < .01; "---"=non-significant 1 2 3 4

We examined the group differences in face categorization's mean correct RT and accuracy rates, in the following mixed ANOVA design: Participants' race (Asian, Caucasian) × Face Race (Asian, Caucasian) as between-subject and within-subject factors, correspondingly. The results showed that neither the two effects nor the interaction between the two factors were significant (for the RT analysis the p >.32, for the accuracy analysis the lowest p >.167). The finding indicated that no systematic other-race effect could be observed at the group level data.

To avoid potential data aggregation issues in data interpretation (Estes & Maddox, 2005, Fifić, 2014Liew, Howe & Little, 2016) we further examined the mean correct RTs and accuracy data at the individual level. We showed the results of a dependent measures t-test, Face Race (Asian, Caucasian), in Table 8. At the mean correct RT level, we observed the other-race effect for 5 out of 10 subjects (c3, c5, a1, a2, and a3). At the accuracy level we observed the other race-effect for 3 out of 10 (c2, c5, and a2).

Moreover, the consistent other-race effects across both the RT and response accuracy were confirmed in only 2 out of 10 cases (c5 and a2). In contrast, three subjects showed the opposite of the other-race effect, the inverse other race effects at the correct RT mean level (c4, a4, and a5), and six subjects showed the inverse effect at the response accuracy level (c1, c4, a1, a3, a4, a5) that is the advantage of processing of the otherrace face, at both mean RT and accuracy levels. The results of the individual-level analysis showed variability in face processing effects, that was not consistent across the manipulated conditions of the Participant Race and Face Race factors, thus corroborating the group mean analysis.

Both the group-level and individual-level ANOVA results failed to provide strong support for a consistent other-race effect for all observers. A reasonable explanation for the absence of the other-race effect is that it could be due to the adjustments of the discriminability of configural facial feature effect, conducted after the psychophysical phase of the study. This step could create perceptually similar second-order relational features, across different Face Race and Participant Race conditions. By making the second-order relational features approximately equally discriminable (salient), the difference in facial categorization between participants' races could be diminished.

By employing computational modeling and model selection, we analyze the data for each subject across different race stimulus sets. By exploring values of the model parameters, we can make inferences about underlying mechanistic processes in holistic and analytic encoding.

div.head: Quantitative Model Fitting
div.p: One way to explore MSPN's validity is to demonstrate its superiority over simpler models using model selection procedures (Myung & Pitt, 2004). We tested five computational models, four of which were special cases of the MSPN: (1) serial selfterminating, (2) independent parallel self-terminating, 3 Table 7. Overall, MSPN showed advantage over other nested models. Considering the average BIC, MSPN shows dominance over the serial, parallel, parallel interactive, and coactive models, respectively across all comparisons, for all participants. These results support the validity of the MSPN's modularity assumption.

When compared to the free-drift model, MSPN comes very close to the benchmark values. In fact, it is notable that the averaged BIC scores are smaller for the MSPN than that of the free-drift model in 15 out of 20 comparisons. This supports the constructive validity of MSPN. What may be a surprising result is that in 13 out of 20 comparison cases (Table 7), the MSPN best fitting log-likelihood values are lower than that of the free-drift model. This means that the parameter constrained MSPN provides a better fit to data than the free-drift model, with fewer parameters (19 vs 21). We will bring up this finding in the discussion section.

To learn about the specific cognitive and perceptual properties of the model across important experimental conditions, we will turn to analysis of the recovered best MSPN parameters reported in Table 8. The parameters are divided between two modules, the serial (left) and parallel (middle) modules, and the module shared (right) parameters.

We use the estimated MSPN parameter values to explore perceptual/cognitive properties of facial perception. We are looking for evidence to support hierarchical organization of the facial representations and the mechanistic properties behind facial perception in the light of the analytic/holistic encoding. To answer these questions, we pay special attention to (1) the modularity gate parameter which indicates the likelihood of trial-to-trial switching between serial and parallel modules, pmod and to (2) the parameter of cross-featural interaction, pcross, only for the parallel model. The two parameter values are presented in Table 8.

In general, these parameter values are interpretable, showing values that range within acceptable values. In all cases, for example, the decision boundaries (Dlips-to-nose and Deye-eye) for both the serial and parallel modules that are used to partition each stimulus dimension (Figure 1, 2-d face space on the left) into response regions are approximately positioned around values of 3 on both dimensions with some individual subject variation. This implies that participants may be using decision rules on featural dimensions to separate the stimulus conditions into two response categories, one of which would satisfy the conjoint rule (Category A region, Figure 1) and one to satisfy the disjoint rule (Redundant Category B, region Figure 1). Not all of the subjects had decision boundary values at the most optimal points (around value 4; see e.g., subject c2, Asian face), which led to mis-categorizations of some of the faces.

MSPN provided very good fits to both correct and incorrect RT distributions across most of the facial conditions. Note MSPN is able to capture very complex response patterns of individual subjects' RT distributions. For example, in Appendix G Figure G Subject c1 Asian faces, the pattern of RT distributions shows that some faces near the category imaginary decision bounds (for example, the distributions across the third row and across the second column, assuming the origin is in the lower left corner)

were not categorized correctly by the participant. A pattern of undecisive respondingshowed that there was a close to equal split between correct and incorrect response distributions but not in all cases. However, MSPN was able to successfully capture these intricate patterns of RT distribution for both correct and incorrect responses.

div.head: Overall facial perception in testing holistic vs analytic encoding
div.p: The average pmod parameter values across all subjects and conditions showed that, across the study trials, subjects were engaged 63% in parallel processing, and 37% in serial processing (pmod = .63). We observed some individual differences, which showed that one subject was almost systematically serial in facial processing (c4 in Asian face condition) showing almost 90% of cases of strict seriality (pmod =.1), but other subjects showed dominant tendency for parallel processing (c2 in Caucasian face conditions) showing almost 90% parallel processing trials (pmod =.9). Most of the subjects showed a higher propensity for using the parallel module. This dominance of parallel over serial processing was also supported in the comparison of the nested models (the models 1-4 in Table 9).

In MSPN, the average cross-featural interaction pcross value indicated that the amount of interaction between featural analyzers, was on average 28% of exchanged sampled featural evidence (pcross =.28), when parallel processing of facial features was diagnosed. The signatures of serial processing strongly support the presence of analytic encoding and active use of facial parts, independently of the facial wholeness. The signatures of parallel processing suggest, in the absence of process interactivity, a weak holistic encoding in which facial features were processed simultaneously, but that still could be accessed individually. The presence of the process interactivity between featural detectors strongly supports the holistic encoding and implies that on some trials subjects either used holistic face representations, or a partly combined facial representations, above the featural properties.

Overall, we can conclude that the subjects showed the evidence of a mixture of serial and parallel processing, with more tendency to parallel processing. In terms of the support for the analytic/holistic debate, the results showed evidence for both encodings. The results strongly support the modularity of the facial processing and also the existence of hierarchical organization of facial representations.

div.head: The Other-Race effect
div.p: We analyzed the MSPN parameters specifically focusing on pmod and pcross, conditioned on the congruency between face race and participate race (same, other). On average, no evidence is observed to support the hypothesis that the same-and otherrace conditions exhibit a propensity toward serial or parallel.
The MSPN best fitting parameter values (Table 8) showed that 4 out of 5

Caucasian subjects were mainly relying on the parallel module in both the same-race and other-race faces (c2, and c5). It is interesting to note that one subject (c4) consistently relied on serial module in processing both types of faces. Likewise, the Asian subjects showed an increase in proportions of parallel processing, and decrease in serial processing, when switching from the same-to the other-race face (Table 8).

This finding is consistent with the idea that other-race faces are more likely to engage the analytic than holistic encoding. When the amount of interaction between featural analyzers is observed, then on average both groups show the expected trend under the current holistic hypothesis's: Judging by the pcross values, both subject race groups, Asians and Caucasians, showed a slight increase in the amount of interaction between featural units, when processing same-race rather than other-race faces Mean[ pCross ]same race = .32, sd=.41, Mean[ pcross ]other race = .24, sd=.34. However, the effect failed to reach significance.

div.head: The Participant Race effect
div.p: One can also compare the MSPN parameters values between the two race groups, Asians and Caucasians. First, there is no significant difference between the two race groups on the amount of parallel/serial processing Mean The results indicated that both groups showed on average similar properties of facial perception.

div.head: General Discussion
div.p: This Table 1).

Through its application in the composite face task and part-to-whole task, MSPN has demonstrated effectiveness in identifying the architecture underlying behavior in these two central paradigms. We next briefly discuss the main findings of MSPN's application as an exploratory tool, leveraging model fitting results to elucidate its capacity to validate or falsify theoretical constructs related to facial perception.

div.head: Application to the Composite Face Task
div.p: MSPN has identified conditions under which holistic processing (or application of an overlearned attentional strategy) is more likely to occur, such as the alignment of facial halves, and has provided quantitative measures that support the theory's validity.

Not only do the different modules of MSPN support the idea of hierarchical representation and the amount of holism exhibited across aligned and misaligned conditions-showing that more parallel and interactive processes are likely in aligned compared to misaligned conditions (see Table 2)-but the results also demonstrate that the recovered parameters from the MSPN model are consistent with this finding (see Table 3). The MSPN parameters corroborated the view that in the aligned condition, This thinking leads us to another important finding in the study, concerning the validity of the hallmark of holistic perception, that is, the interaction between Alignment × Congruency d' values. A significant amount of research is devoted solely to the analysis of the interaction term, often neglecting other stimulus conditions. In effect, the Alignment × Congruency interaction is considered a sufficient and necessary indicator of holistic processing. Intriguingly, we show that several analytic models can also predict an Alignment × Congruency interaction (the pure serial model, see Table 4).

The fact that strictly analytic processing can qualitatively predict the hallmark interaction signature questions the validity of using the composite face paradigm to detect holistic processing. Addressing the question of why selective attention fails in the composite task, the answer likely lies in the engagement of the non-target facial part, but it cannot be unequivocally argued that this is due to pooling of information from across the entire face. Further research is advised, following these findings, by applying MSPN to a larger data set of published works if available.

div.head: Application to the Part-to-Whole Face Task
div.p: Model fitting revealed that different modules, capable of embodying either a more holistic or more analytic approach, fit the empirical data equally well across a variety of conditions including the processing of inverted faces and non-face objects.

This finding introduces a significant challenge to the validation of the part-to-whole paradigm as a definitive measure of holistic versus analytic processing. Specifically, the fact that several different MSPN modules could fit the data well suggests that the order of accuracy across conditions in the part-to-whole task may not be as diagnostic as previously believed.

Interestingly, MSPN not only allowed some inference about processing of faces but also provided good fits to the house stimuli used by Tanaka and Sengco (1997; see Table 5). In all three experiments, both the serial and parallel modules of MSPN were able to capture the data almost perfectly.

Our research supports the idea that our cognitive/perceptual operations use a hierarchical process to recognize faces. The implication is that processing might start by examining at specific features and then combining those features together to understand the whole face or object (cf. Lynch, Cheng, & Little, 2021). In simple terms, our work highlights the complexity of how we perceive the world around us and suggests that the MSPN model could be a valuable tool for future research in understanding these processes better.

In general, the insights offered by MSPN advocate for a more comprehensive approach to data collection and analysis, encompassing both correct and incorrect RTs, as well as examining a broader range of conditions beyond the conventional metrics (e.g., Alignment × Congruency interaction in the composite face task).

div.head: Application to the Other-Race Face Effect
div.p: In the current study, we were able to analyze holistic/analytic processing properties through estimated best fit parameters. Individual subject estimates of pmod indicate the proportion of trials cases in which subjects would use serial and parallel modules. Some subjects showed a propensity for pure serial processing (Table 7 and Table 8 after inspection of the pmod recovered parameter values -c4 for both face conditions, and a3 for the Caucasian face condition) while some showed for pure parallel processing (c2, c3, and a1 for the both face types, for example). Overall, close analysis of the recovered best fitting MSPN model parameters indicated that subjects were mainly relying on parallel processing of facial features. This finding is corroborated by many publications assuming that facial perception, that is usually considered to be the holistic, is presumably conducted in parallel (e.g., Matthews, 1978;Sergent, 1984;Wenger & Townsend, 2001;Fifić & Townsend, 2010;cf. Fitousi, 2021).
This result is in accordance with the first axiom of Wenger and Townsend (2001),
assuming that the parallel should be considered as more holistic than the serial processing.

With regards to the second axiom, the scope of information search, the estimates of the amount of termination can be determined by the fact that the MSPN model itself represents a good fit to the data, when compared to the free drift model, which doesn't have an assumption of the search scope. This validates the model's central assumptions that the category A group will be processed exhaustively and the category B group will be processed using a self-terminating strategy. 6
The cross-talk parameter, pcross, indicates the amount of process interactivity.

This parameter varied across different subjects and conditions. An increase in the crosstalk between simple features processing units increases the amount of exchanged information between featural detectors represented here as two random walks. When such two processes start to exchange sampled featural evidence, they bind together.

One can see that such binding could act as a superordinate feature. In terms of the hierarchy of facial representations, an interaction creates a novel higher-level complex feature, and at the same time disables access to the constituent features. Varying the amount of interactivity one can switch between two different perceptual states: one 6 Note that the definition of the type of logical rules used in the MSPN model, is neither arbitrary, nor determined ad-hoc. A nature of the binary task is that there is always one response category which contains a target (target present) and the other response category which doesn't contain the target (target absent). The target, in the current study, is a facial feature that can be solely used to make a final decision -and these are the facial features associated with the top, left group of faces in Figure 2 eye-to-eye values less than 4 and lips-to-nose values that are less than 4).

between seeing parts and another one seeing whole objects. By and large, these states correspond to analytic and holistic encoding hypotheses. In accordance with Wenger and Townsend Axiom 3 (2001), the increase in interaction between processing features supports evidence for holistic encoding. Across all subjects and face types, the model fitting results showed a low amount of interactivity when parallel module was used (the average value of pcross=.28) implying a weak level of holism. The overall finding is consistent with the idea that a moderate amount of holistic encoding was involved in our task.

Model comparison and analysis of the estimated parameters showed trends toward the other-race effect even though our statistical tests did not reach conventional significance levels. One way to address this would be to collect more individuals; the other race face effect is typically observed at the group-level rather than the individuallevel. We note, however, that the goal of our study was to collect sufficient RT data per facial condition so that the RT distributions could be fit for each individual and each item. This represents a different goal to usual other-race face effect studies (cf. and could explain why we failed to find a significant effect. In future, it is advisable to sample both a larger set of participants and a larger sample of faces. Such face variance should improve generalizability of the current study (see e.g., Baribault et al., 2018).

Another potentially confounding factor that could diminish the other-race effect in our study is the effect of experience with other race faces. Prolonged exposure to other race-faces reduces the other-race effect (e.g., Goldstein, & Chance, 1985;Hancock & Rhodes, 2008;Wan et al., 2015;Lindsay, Jack & Christian, 1991; see the review in Young et al. 2012). This is likely not the case in our study, as we sampled subjects from two geographically separated populations (Taiwan and USA). Although some cross-race exposure of the other race-faces is possible through shared media (such as movies), we suspect that the bulk of the exposure of our participants has occurred within own-race faces. It is somewhat unlikely that the shared facial environment could dilute a possible other-race effect in our study.

A more likely reason for the absence of the other-race effect is due to the feature discriminability adjustment conducted in the psychophysical phase of the current study (see Blaha, 2017, for similar arguments). This step was done to counter off the effect of possible individual-subjects and the cross-race difference in facial feature detections.

First, the individual-subject differences in detection of facial features, could be a significant source of random subject variability, that could affect detection of the true processing properties, when aggregated subject data is used. As hinted above, the aggregated data could be used for inference only if the subject groups are homogeneous with respect to the perceptual mechanism they use. Aggregation of such data (such as averaging) would lead to unbiased estimates of the statistical parameters of interest.

However, the homogeneity status of subject groups is not known. If groups are sampled of non-homogenous subjects, then data aggregation could lead to systematic biases in data interpretation and inference.

Given that we found the weak other-race effect for both Asians and Caucasians we could argue that this result was due to the individual adjustments of perceptual effects. Presumably, the equal adjustment of feature salience created an equal perceptual effect for different race faces. Although, the result contradicts a large body of the other-race effect literature, including the authors' recent publication , the current study pointed to a potentially very important confound in the crossrace facial studies. More research is needed to further explore and document the populational norms in facial properties distribution, which could provide valuable insights and strengthen the generalizability of the findings (Wang, et al, 2022;Wen, Wong & McGrath, 2017;Danel, et al, 2018;Wen et al, 2015;Kalina, 2011;Fang, Clapham & Chung, 2011;Goldstein, 1979). Recent trends indicated an increasing interest in developing methods to control for individual subject differences in various domains of cognitive modelling. One such approach calls for the use of so-called adaptive experimental designs, in which the individual differences are adjusted on a trial-to-trials bases during a study participation (e.g., Watson & Pelli, 1983;Glavan, et al., 2019; the tutorial is provided in Myung, Cavagnaro & Pitt, 2013).

Finally, a large body of published research suggest absence of the other-race effect, at least with some racial groups (Tanaka, Kiefer, & Bukach, 2004;Michel, Caldara, & Rossion, 2006;Mondloch et al., 2010). Other research suggests that this effect sometimes can be reversed (Caldara et al., 2004;Ge et al., 2009;Levin, 1996Levin, , 2000Valentine & Endo, 1992;Zhao & Bentin, 2008). In any case, further research holds great potential to uncover new insights into the other-race effect in cognitive tasks. The current study offers a valuable foundation and clear directions to inspire and guide these future discoveries.

div.head: Limitations and future research recommendations
div.p: The current findings underscore the necessity for a more detailed approach to model validation and the interpretation of data in cognitive science. We highlight the importance of comprehensive datasets that encompass a broader range of conditions and response metrics to constrain model predictions and enhance their falsifiability. As such, the discussion surrounding the composite face task and the part-to-whole paradigm urges researchers in facial area studies to move beyond the most popularly reported signatures and instead rely on more complete datasets that can provide a firmer foundation for theoretical conclusions and model validations.

Our use of MSPN both as an exploratory tool and as a full processing theoretical framework marks it as a pivotal distinction in cognitive science. As an exploratory tool, its application aims at probing existing theories and uncovering empirical evidence.

Conversely, when MSPN is harnessed as a theoretical framework, it assumes a more foundational role, structuring and guiding the development of comprehensive theories that encompass the entirety of cognitive processing involved in phenomena like the other-race effect. This dual capacity of MSPN not only amplifies its versatility but also enhances its contribution to advancing our understanding of complex cognitive processes.

Another future extension would be to apply MSPN to different tasks. In the present paper, we applied MSPN to a categorization task, which has been validated in many research papers (Townsend & Nozawa, 1995;Fifić, Townsend & Eidels 2008;Fifić, Nosofsky & Townsend, 2008;Fifić, Little & Nosofsky, 2010;Griffiths, Blunden & Little, 2017;Fitousi & Algom, 2018;Fifić, Houpt & Rieskamp, 2019; for tutorial see Fifić & Little, 2017), some of which covered facial perception (Fifić, 2006;Fifić & Townsend, 2010;Cheng et al, 2018;Cheng & Little, 2025;Fitousi, 2021). To improve generalizability, it would be interesting to extend the SFT double factorial paradigm to other types of decisions and to apply MSPN. For instance, similar modelling approaches have been recently developed for change detection tasks (Blunden et al., 2022;Fong et al., 2024). Consequently, we would recommend conducting a large scale, double factorial composite face task involving aligned, misaligned, upright and inverted face stimuli, and then applying MSPN to infer processing in each condition. To avoid potential budgetary limitations incurred by relying on large data set collection, another suggestion would be to integrate the MSPN model with the adaptive design approaches, presumably focused on the hierarchical Bayesian modelling. Hierarchical approaches are very effective in ameliorating issues of nominal identification of perceptual/cognitive strategies and could be combined with individual data analysis (e.g., Wiecki, Sofer & Frank, 2013;Houpt, Heathcote & Eidels, 2017;Houpt & Fifić, 2017). Such methods, although computationally intensive, would provide a posterior likelihood identification of groups of subjects with similar cognitive strategies, for a smaller data set.

div.head: Relation to existing theories
div.p: MSPN synthesizes several successful theoretical approaches such as signal detection, random walks, serial/parallel architectures, and parallel interactive process.

These concepts allowed for integration of the idea of hierarchical facial (object) representation that are linked to cognitive processes. The backend of the model can be used to assess different properties of both mental representations and processes engaged.

In the domain of facial perception, MSPN can be used to further structurally decompose facial perceptual processes and to clarify vagueness in the theoretical constructs of the analytic vs holistic encoding.

MSPN is an extension of the logical-rule models (Fifić, Little & Nosofsky, 2010), including a parametrized modular system for processing (serial vs parallel) that also includes an interactive gating system between processes in the parallel model. The logical-rule models are nested with the MSPN.

One of the most important contributions of this paper is further development of the computational approach for parallel interactive models and its application on the complex categorization task. Such a model can be compared to the other similar evidence accumulation models, that have been applied in various cognitive and perceptual full processing models (e.g., Ashby, 1989;Ashby, 2000;Nosofsky & Palmeri, 1997;Cox & Shiffrin, 2017; and for the overview of different evidence accumulation methods read Ratcliff, et al., 2016). A large part of computational modelling of interactive processing has been focused on testing the properties of the coactive processing model (Miller, 1982;Schwarz,1989;Townsend & Nozawa, 1995;Diederich, 1995;Townsend & Wenger, 2004;Fifić, Nosofsky & Townsend, 2008;Fifić, & Townsend, 2010;Howard et al., 2021;Gondan & Blurton, 2013;Yang, Altieri & Little, 2018;Little, Eidels, Fifić, & Wang, 2015Fitousi & Algom, 2020).

With relationship to other face theories, MSPN operationalizes Townsend and Wenger's (2004;Wenger & Townsend, 2001) three foundational axioms-processing order, stopping rules, and process interdependency-providing a structured basis for testing, validating, or falsifying key theoretical accounts of holistic face perception.

Specifically, MSPN's parametric structure, characterized by parameters such as serialparallel modularity (pmod ) and cross-channel interaction (pcross ), offers a powerful tool for empirical evaluation of prominent face-processing theories outlined in Table 1. The configural processing theory (Diamond & Carey, 1986) The interactive processing model (Fifić & Townsend, 2010) posits that holistic effects arise from graded interactivity among facial features. Coactivity could be considered as a special case of the parallel interactive model in which all featural accumulation evidence is exchanged between working evidence accumulators. Work on coactive models has been developed over several decades and reached a peak with the recent development of the non-parametric tests for the coactive processing (Miller, 1982;Townsend & Nozawa, 1995;. However, the extensive search for coactive model signatures, across wide research on holistic properties, has not been always successful (e.g., Eidels, Townsend & Pomerantz, 2008;Eidels, Townsend, Hughes Perry, 2015;Cheng et al. 2018;Yang, Altieri & Little, 2018) (c.f. Fifić, Nosofsky & Townsend, 2008Fifić, & Townsend, 2010). The present approach, which allows detection of a graded amount of parallel interactivity, provides an important alternative to the application of pure coactive model. MSPN directly validates this theory by enabling measurement of intermediate interaction values (0 < pcross < 1). Our findings confirm intermediate interactivity levels, aligning closely with interactive processing theory predictions. Pure serial (pmod = 0, pcross = 0) or purely independent parallel processing (pcross = 0) would falsify this graded interaction perspective.

In our findings, this theory was partly confirmed as MSPN identified clear evidence for parallel interactivity among feature detectors across multiple tasks, supporting the graded interaction hypothesis. However, we also found consistent evidence for a mixture of serial (analytic) and parallel processing within the same tasks, suggesting that holistic face processing does not exclusively rely on parallel interactivity. These results align closely but not exclusively with the interactive processing model, highlighting MSPN's capacity to reveal nuanced cognitive architectures underlying facial perception.

The Overlearned Attention Hypothesis (Chua, Richler, & Gauthier, 2014 provides an alternative account of holistic perception, attributing holistic effects to learned attentional strategies rather than innate face-specific mechanisms. According to this perspective, experience and expertise progressively stabilize and refine memory representations, leading to higher drift rates and reduced variance, while the processing architecture (serial or parallel) and interactivity parameters (pmod, pcross) remain stable.

MSPN framework provides a way to empirically identify the mechanisms that arise as attentional patterns are learned by detecting whether holistic effects arise due to changes in attentional weighting (drift rate, variance) or structural changes in perceptual organization (pmod, pcross). While MSPN did not directly validate the learning-dependent changes at the memory representation level independently of architecture or interactivity parameters, it did reveal systematic shifts in parameters like pmod and pcross across different task conditions (see also Fific & Townsend, 2010 for converging evidence).

Critically, the fitting results from the composite face paradigm in the current study support the idea that the so-called holistic effect in the aligned composite face task arises from cross-item facilitation. This is evidenced by the high value of the pcross parameter in the aligned condition, which was significantly greater than in the misaligned condition. However, there remains a shadow of doubt regarding the validity of the composite face paradigm in supporting the "holistic effects" and consequently the predictions of the overlearned attentional theory. Specifically, the pure serial model, which allows for perfectly selective attention to individual facial parts, also demonstrated-albeit weakly (Table 4)-a signature of the holistic effect in the composite face task. This raises concerns about the Overlearned Attentional theory, as the serial model serves as a baseline reference for purely analytic featural processing.

The fact that holistic-like effects still emerge under a serial framework suggests that the composite face paradigm, which is often associated with the Overlearned Attention theory, may not be an adequate tool to clearly differentiate between competing explanations. Instead, more refined methodologies that directly test interactivity versus attentional weighting mechanisms are needed to fully assess the validity of the Overlearned Attentional theory. Thus, the results highlight the need for a more detailed theoretical approach that integrates both attentional mechanisms and structural modifications in perceptual processing rather than attributing holistic effects solely to overlearned attentional strategies.

Finally, the failure of selective attention hypothesis (as reviewed in argues that holistic face effects result from attentional limitations rather than actual integration of facial features. Importantly, this hypothesis does not represent a unified theoretical model but rather a broadly defined construct operationalized differently across various tasks and contexts. MSPN can clarify these distinct mechanistic possibilities by operationalizing attentional failure as minimal parallel interaction with primarily serial processing (pmod = 0, pcross = 0). However, if MSPN reveals substantial parallel processing (pmod > 0) or clear interactive integration (pcross > 0), this would suggest genuine holistic mechanisms beyond mere attentional failures.

Across all studies, we found evidence that the perceptual system attempted to use selective attention, mainly through engagement of the serial self-terminating system, which, when combined with accurate memory representations, allows clear-cut selective attention to a single feature without interaction. For instance, in the other-race study, one Caucasian subject (c4, Tables 7 and 8) exhibited systematic serial selective attention across both race conditions, demonstrating a high level of analytic processing.

Moreover, MSPN analyses of the composite face and part-to-whole tasks revealed that results could be successfully explained by the serial self-terminating model. It should be noted that in the composite face task, the serial model itself demonstrated prediction of the Alignment × Congruency interaction (pure serial model; see Table 4), whereas in the part-to-whole paradigm, this purely analytic model was able to tightly fit all conditions, emerging as a strong candidate model. This outcome highlights a limitation identified earlier: reliance on a single dependent measure, such as accuracy, may deflate model falsifiability. Our analysis clearly demonstrates this. In the composite task, joint RT and accuracy modeling was possible (Gao et al., 2011), but full datasets are rarely published. In the part-to-whole task, we only analyzed accuracies provided by authors (Tanaka & Sengco, 1997); thus, it remains an open question whether MSPN model fits would change if complete datasets were jointly analyzed.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: The application of MSPN to traditional face processing paradigms such as the composite face task and part-to-whole paradigm allows for a novel understanding of facial perception mechanisms. By validating the importance of holistic processing in the composite face task and elucidating the conditions under which analytic processing prevails in the part-to-whole paradigm, MSPN has proven to be an effective exploratory tool.

Our findings pose significant challenges to the traditional paradigms that seek to differentiate facial processing strategies solely based on the holistic versus analytic dichotomy. These novel insights from the MSPN model fitting significantly contribute to the ongoing discourse on facial processing, advocating for a more refined approach that transcends the binary of holistic versus analytic processing, and instead considers the dynamic, context-dependent nature of facial perception.

For example, if at a single step both processes sampled evidence toward the bound A, and the parameter pcross allows "open" communication gate between two accumulators, then each accumulator would increase the value of evidence toward bound A for one more unit.
In sum, in the present applications, MSPN uses the following 19 free parameters.

Eight parameters belongs to the serial module: pser,, σx-ser 2 , σy-ser 2 , Dx-ser, Dy-ser, +A ser, -B ser,, Sw (which is the time that corresponds to switching from one to another process); seven parameters belongs to the parallel module: σx-par 2 , σy-par 2 , Dx-par, Dy-par, +A par, -B

For the nested models, the serial model has 11 free parameters (those described above in the serial module plus the scale parameter, k, and the two residual time parameters). The parallel model has 9 free parameters, those described in the parallel module plus the scale parameter (k), and the two residual time parameters, excluding the pcross parameter. The parallel interactive model has 10 free parameters, that is the 9 from the parallel model plus the pcross parameter, which specifies a level of information exchange at each step of random walk. The coactive model is a special case of the parallel interactive model in which the pcross parameter is set to maximum of 1, which leaves 9 free parameters. The free-drift model has 21 free parameters; 16 free parameters that are used to drive the 16 random walks, each corresponding to one facial condition from the design. To generate predictions for each stimulus, we performed 10,000 simulations for each individual stimulus, resulting in a total of 540,000 random walk simulations for the entire response time dataset (6 × 9 × 10,000). Quantiles were calculated for each of the 6 × 9 conditions in the simulated study.

For each individual stimulus, observed correct and incorrect RTs were segmented into quantile-based bins. All three dataset's quantiles were fitted using the full MSPN model, allowing all model parameters to vary freely. The fitting process involved 10,000 simulations for each stimulus, resulting in 540,000 random walk simulations for the entire dataset for each simulation during a single step of the parameter optimization process. Additionally, we conducted our computer searches for the best-fitting parameters using 200 different random starting configurations of the parameter values.
The best-fitting recovered parameters presented in Table B1 demonstrate that the MSPN was able to accurately recover the parameter values used in the simulation.

Additionally, the MSPN model correctly recovered the parameter values of pmod across all different types of data simulations, as well as the value of pcross. This observation highlights that the MSPN is less prone to misidentifying the correct processing order (serial vs. parallel) and is also less likely to misidentify the presence or absence of process interaction with any other parameter used in the model. 0.99 5.05 0.9 10.65 1 Note: Parameter values were omitted (dash line) when a single module was used across all trials (that is pmod =0 or pmod =1). MSPN Properties, Levels of Hierarchical Facial Representation, and the Spectrum of Holistic Processing MSPN's computational properties and mechanisms are deeply rooted in Townsend and Wenger's foundational axioms of perceptual holism and analytic processing

Appendix A). At the basic hierarchical level of facial representations lie the fundamental principles governing the organization of memory representations. MSPN models psychological representations of face stimuli as perceptual distributions along multiple facial feature dimensions, with each memorized representation characterized by both a mean (μ) and a variance (σ²). The mean value (μ) represents the most likely location of the memory representation along a given feature dimension, while the variance (σ²) serves as a critical parameter quantifying the discriminability and memory stability of each feature dimension. A smaller variance indicates higher perceptual precision and stability of facial features in memory, whereas greater variance reflects perceptual uncertainty and weaker representations.

Whereas representation-based coactivity models assume a single integrated processing channel from the outset, MSPN's parallel interactive framework maintains separate feature channels with explicit inter-channel interactions that dynamically exchange evidence during processing. The distinction between these two theoretical conceptions becomes empirically testable when examining patterns of interaction across experimental manipulations of face perception. MSPN provides a rigorous computational framework capable of differentiating whether holistic effects are due primarily to early representational integration (single-channel coactivity) or dynamic interactive processing occurring later during the accumulation of evidence. Consequently, MSPN serves as a valuable tool for resolving debates regarding the precise mechanistic locus of holistic processing-whether it arises from stable representational templates or from dynamic interactions among facial features at the decisional processing stage.

Conversely, falsification of the failure of selective attention hypothesis as a simple attentional limitation would occur if MSPN showed evidence for parallel processing (pmod > 0) or interactive feature integration (pcross > 0). If features are found to be truly interdependent, then selective attention failure would reflect genuine holistic processing rather than an attentional constraint. Moreover, MSPN's ability to model drift rates, decision boundaries, and process interactivity provides a means to distinguish between perceptual-level integration, attentional biases, and response-based interference, offering a more precise mechanistic account of face perception. By systematically varying key parameters such as feature interactivity (pcross), processing architecture (pmod ), memory variance, and drift rates, MSPN provides a formal computational framework to test, validate, and falsify competing theories of holistic face perception. Unlike traditional behavioral methods, which rely on indirect inferences, MSPN offers a mechanistic approach that quantitatively evaluates how different processing strategies contribute to face perception. This approach advances the field by allowing for stronger model validation, clearer distinctions between competing theories, and a deeper understanding of the cognitive mechanisms underlying holistic face processing.

. Like MSPN, the MADD model emphasizes flexibility in cognitive strategy selection and demonstrates how modular architectures can produce complex decision-making behavior. However, while MADD provides a general framework for serial and parallel processing orders, it does not specify memory storage for representations, a key feature of MSPN. Together, these models illustrate the shared principle of adaptability through modularity, highlighting how modular cognitive architectures facilitate flexible and context-sensitive decision-making. Identifiability of the nested models within the MSPN framework MSPN combines several modes of processing in a single network capturing the idea that cognitive functions related to face perception are interconnected and organized hierarchically. Individual cognitive models within this framework can be seen as modules or components contributing to the overall process of face perception. MSPN aids in understanding the flow of hierarchical information between these modules, shedding light on their collective contribution to face perception. MSPN can be approached from two distinct perspectives: one as an overarching structure encompassing various face perception modules (from completely analytic to strongly holistic) designed specifically for the operational purposes of measuring modularity and independence, and the other as a comprehensive computational account of face processing that captures the flexibility exhibited across tasks. From the first viewpoint, MSPN acts as an umbrella for analyzing face perceptual processes or as an exploratory tool. It serves as a unifying structure, bringing together a diverse range of face perception models under one overarching framework. MSPN acts as an umbrella by providing a theoretical scaffolding, enabling researchers to integrate and comprehend different face perceptual processes within the broader context of human face cognition.

Within MSPN, decisional bias is incorporated as part of the psychological constructs used in memory processes and evidence retrieval from memory representations (for example, a decision-bound Dx, Appendix A), as well as a criterion in the random walk module, which sets the threshold for evidence accumulation needed to elicit a response (for example +A, -B response bound values, Appendix A). Thus, MSPN provides a comprehensive theoretical framework to address response biases in facial processing. By leveraging MSPN, we aim to enhance our understanding of the complex dynamics of facial perception and to illuminate the mechanisms underlying holistic processing. 7. Modulation of Interactivity: MSPN's parameter pcross modulates the amount of cross-talk between random walks, influencing the level of featural interdependency. This modulation links the results to the hierarchical structure of facial representations, offering insights into how holistic encoding emerges. In summary, MSPN provides a unified computational framework that addresses the limitations of the composite face paradigm by offering a flexible, modular, and interactive approach. It not only explains the joint analysis of RT and accuracy but also captures individual differences, response biases, and the hierarchical nature of facial representations, providing a more detailed understanding of the composite face effect.

Analytic models, including the single-dimensional, serial, parallel, and the mixture of serial and parallel models, are expected to exhibit a null Congruency × Alignment interaction. By contrast, the parallel interactive model, as well as the mixture of serial and parallel interactive processes within MSPN, are anticipated to show non-zero interaction values indicating strong holistic properties. By contrast, in the misaligned condition, pure serial processing provides a superior fit compared to most of the other models, including the parallel model, suggesting strong analytic encoding.Moreover, the recovered parameters across all models align with the aforementioned observations. Notably, MSPN's best-fitting parameters reveal a distinct segregation between aligned and misaligned conditions indicating a hierarchical structure: In the aligned condition, pmod = .9, indicating that 90% of trials utilized the parallel module, and pcross = 1, suggesting maximal interactivity among features thus supporting strong holistic encoding. In contrast, in the misaligned condition, pmod = .17, signifying that only 17% of trials engage the parallel module, and 83% of trials utilized the serial module. Additionally, pcross= .46 indicates a moderate level of interactivity among the 17% of parallel trials, primarily supporting the analytic hypothesis and weakly supporting the presence of holistic encoding.

Why would processing of the irrelevant facial part occur at all? One explanation is a failure of selective attention, where the perceptual system is inclined to analyze all facial features, hinting at holistic processing, as described by Townsend & Wenger's continuum of holistic processing. This highlights how a failure of selective attention,

isolated parts < P(c) new configuration < P(c) old configuration. Here is a summary of the observed ordering: P(c) isolated parts: After studying Joe's face, Joe's eyes are displayed on their own, without any other facial features. This isolated presentation typically leads to lower recognition accuracy due to the absence of contextual cues. P(c) new configuration: Joe's eyes are paired with other facial features in an unusual arrangement. Recognition rates are improved compared to the isolated parts condition, suggesting that the inclusion of additional features facilitates identification. P(c) old configuration: Joe's eyes are presented in their normal facial configuration resulting in the highest recognition accuracy, underscoring the brain's use of holistic processing for effective facial recognition. This distinct pattern of responses strongly supports the concept of holistic facial perception, challenging the idea that selective encoding of individual features suffices to explain recognition outcomes. Nevertheless, this pattern of performance is also consistent with an overlearned attentional strategy, which is preserved in the old configuration condition but not in the other conditions. (Presumably the new configuration condition allows for configural information to guide attention in a manner that the isolated attention condition does not).

figure.figDesc: Taiwanese students (4 M, 1 F; ages 18-25) from National Cheng Kung University and five US students (3 M, 2 F; ages range between 19-21) from Grand Valley State University were reimbursed NTD 200 and USD 10 per session, for their participation, respectively. All of the participants completed a large number of trials, hence, following the principles of a small-N design (Little & Smith, 2018; Smith & Little, 2018). All the participants had normal or corrected-to-normal vision. Each signed a written informed consent prior to the experiment. The ethics approval for the study was obtained from the Ethics Committee of Department of Psychology at National Cheng Kung University and Ethics Committee of Department of Psychology at Grand Valley State University, and the experiment was conducted in accordance with the approved guidelines and regulations.

parallel interactive, (4) coactive, and (5) MSPN. Each model predicts a specific pattern of RTs distributions for both correct and incorrect responses. The tested models were formed by fixing some of MSPN's parameter values (Appendix A). For example, by setting the modular gating parameter to zero, MSPN becomes identical to a (1) Serial self-terminating model; by setting pmod equal to one and pcross equal to 0, MSPN becomes identical to a (2) parallel self-terminating model. By setting pmod equal to 1 and by and by letting the interaction pcross parameter to vary, MSPN is identical to (3) Parallel interactive model. By setting the value of the parallel interactive parameter pcross to one (and setting pmod to 1) MSPN is identical to a (4) coactive model. To further evaluate the validity of the best-fitting model, we compared it to a simpler free-drift model, which is much less constrained than the MSPN. The free-drift model serves as a highly parameterized baseline, making only a few basic assumptions of the MSPN framework-namely, that an evidence accumulation process occurs, defined as the probability of stepping toward a target boundary, with common absorbing boundaries across different stimulus conditions. In contrast, MSPN calculates the stepping probability by determining the proportion of the area under a noisy representation distribution that is bounded by a decision criterion. As such, the stepping values in MSPN are constrained by the stimulus configuration, memory representations, and decisional processes. By comparison, in the free-drift model, these stepping probabilities are treated as unconstrained free parameters. Each face condition is represented as a single noisy distribution sampled using a separate random walk, disconnected from the mechanistic assumptions of MSPN. Consequently, the free-drift model is not logically derived from the MSPN's mechanistic principles and instead functions purely as a statistical model. Its primary role is to serve as a benchmark, with its fitting score used to evaluate the quality of the parameter-constrained MSPN fits. This comparison allows us to assess whether the additional complexity of Hierarchical Face Representations MSPN-grounded in its mechanistic assumptions-is justified. By balancing model fit with complexity (see Appendix F), this analysis highlights that MSPN's parameterconstrained approach offers a theoretically grounded and mechanistically superior account of the observed data relative to the much less constrained free-drift model. The rationale behind inclusions of the simpler model variants is to evaluate whether the additional complexity of MSPN is justified, as a measure that balance a goodness of model fits and model complexity (Appendix F) For each subject's best fitting model (as determined by the BIC), the complete set of predicted correct and incorrect RT distributions are shown along with the observed distributions in Appendix G (Figure G). paper discusses a novel computational framework called the Modular Serial-Parallel Network (MSPN). MSPN integrates various perceptual and cognitive approaches to address the challenges in face perception theories, particularly how to combine holistic and analytic encoding within a unified framework. MSPN is designed to simulate four stages in face perception: representational, decisional, logical-rule implementation, and modular stochastic accrual of information. It offers insights into the dynamics of cognitive processing, illustrating the interplay between holistic and analytic encoding mechanisms. In facial perception research, it is crucial to have models that can accommodate the hierarchical representation of faces, blending holistic and analytic processing. MSPN is proposed to fill this gap, providing a comprehensive model for understanding face perception through a combination of memory representations, signal detection theory, mental architectures, and process interactivity. The hierarchical nature of facial representations suggests that faces are processed at multiple levels, ranging from individual features to holistic gestalts. Understanding facial perception involves recognizing the intricate layers of information encoded within facial features, from basic visual cues to complex cognitive interpretations. The current study details the components of MSPN, elucidating how they encapsulate the hierarchical organization of facial information and contribute to our understanding of perceptual and cognitive mechanisms in facial perception tasks. The model components are identifiable through the free parameter values and can be used to link the observed evidence to assumed model's components. The key MSPN parameters that could be used identify perceptual analytic and holistic properties, are the modularity gate parameter, which indicates the likelihood of trial-to-trial switching between serial and parallel modules, pmod, and the parameter of cross-featural interaction, pCross. In cognitive science, the investigation of facial perception mechanisms stands as a central challenge to understanding human cognition and social interaction. The complexity of these mechanisms demands sophisticated analytical tools capable of disentangling the intricate interplay of cognitive processes involved. MSPN offers dual utility as both an exploratory tool and a comprehensive theoretical framework for full processing analysis (see for instance,

facial features are more likely perceived in a parallel and interactive fashion (by inspection of the pmod and pcross values) than in the misaligned condition.The current findings regarding the composite face task are limited by fitting the model only to average data. To arrive at a conclusive understanding of the underlying processes, interpreting the entire dataset under the MSPN model is required. In practice, research employing the composite face paradigm seldom reports the complete dataset, including both correct and incorrect RTs, as well as response accuracies for all stimulus conditions in the study. Consequently, the model fits of MSPN could significantly vary, potentially being much different or less conclusive, if based solely on partial data instead of the full dataset.

Within the Modular Serial-Parallel Network (MSPN), the face template hypothesis would be supported if evidence accumulation in the parallel-interactive

row.cell: model showed maximal correlation between feature processing units (pcross = 1). This
would indicate full integration of face parts, consistent with a holistic template-based
encoding process. Additionally, if face perception relies on a holistic template, the
system should not allow for early termination of processing, as all components of the
template must be fully integrated to produce a recognition decision. This implies that
in MSPN, pmod should not equal 0, since pure serial processing with self-termination
(pmod = 0, self-terminating) would contradict the assumption of an integrated, holistic
template. Instead, a holistic template-based model would require either parallel
processing or exhaustive serial processing, ensuring that all features contribute to the
recognition decision before a response is made.
Falsification of the face template hypothesis would occur if pcross < 1, indicating
that face components are not fully integrated, or if pmod = 0, suggesting that face
recognition could proceed through serial self-terminating processing rather than
requiring full template activation. Unlike the face template approach, which primarily
relies on behavioral measures such as inversion effects to infer holistic processing,
MSPN's parametric structure allows for direct testing of feature interdependence. By
measuring feature correlations and processing architecture, MSPN offers a more precise
method of evaluating holistic processing beyond what traditional experimental

This allows MSPN to capture the mixture model account proffered by Cheng and Little (see e.g.,Cheng et al., 2018;Cheng & Little, 2025).4. Explaining Individual Differences in Strategies:The modularity of MSPN, with the ability to activate serial or parallel modules probabilistically, using different decision criteria when retrieving information from memory, and dealing with possible speed accuracy adjustments in strategies, accommodates individual differences in cognitive strategies. Participants with different strategic approaches can be captured by adjusting MSPN's parameters.5. Detailed Picture of Composite Face Effect Results and HierarchicalRepresentation: MSPN introduces a hierarchical representation, with serial processing corresponding to lower levels and parallel processing to higher levels of organization of facial representations.
