emphasizes that upright face perception leverages emergent spatial relationships between facial features.MSPN allows this theory to be validated by showing that variations in spatial properties systematically influence the means and variances of memory representations for facial features. For instance, disruptions such as face inversion or misalignment of face halves (e.g.,Thompson, 1980) should affect perceptual sensitivity at the memory level, as reflected by changes in MSPN variance parameters. If spatial properties of facial features were not clearly discriminated or had minimal influence on MSPN's memory parameters, this would falsify configural processing theory. Our empirical results aligned with this theoretical prediction, demonstrating distinct sensitivity to spatial relationships during displacement of canonical first-order configural features, such as lips and eyes, thus supporting this model. Our other-race study results, examining specific configural features in terms of spatial separation, showed that both response times and categorization accuracies are sensitive to spatial separation magnitude, providing additional supporting evidence that these configurations are likely to be perceptually differentiated.The Interactive Configural Processing Theory(Maurer, Le Grand, & Mondloch, 2002) extends the configural processing theory by proposing multiple hierarchical levels of configural and featural integration. Although conceptually broad, this theory lacks detailed specifications of the mechanisms or decision rules governing interactions among these hierarchical levels. MSPN uniquely enables testing these mechanisms by predicting specific changes in the degree of interactivity under various experimental conditions. For example, this account would be supported by findings demonstrating

row.cell: differential cross-channel interaction parameters (pcross ) when faces are aligned (pcross
> 0) compared to misaligned (pcross = 0). Conversely, identical MSPN parameters for
aligned, misaligned, and inverted faces would weaken the hierarchical assumptions of
MSPN indeed revealed differential cross-channel interaction (pcross) between
aligned and misaligned faces in the composite face task, indicating higher interactivity
in the aligned condition, consistent with the theory's predictions. However, the theory
also does not accommodate cases of exclusively featural processing, as observed with
at least one subject (c4) in the other-race study, who consistently exhibited a strictly
featural analysis rather than integrating multiple processing sources. Additionally,
because the theory itself lacks precise specifications regarding the mechanisms or
decision rules governing interactions across hierarchical levels, the MSPN results can
only provide general alignment rather than definitive validation. Thus, although
MSPN's findings partially align with the Interactive Configural Processing Theory, the
support remains constrained by the theory's broad nature and absence of mechanistic

In every instance, the full MSPN yielded the most accurate fits to the data compared to all other models, which is expected since the other models are special cases of MSPN. Notably, MSPN is the only model that can qualitatively account for the observed results. Although MSPN is a more complex model and inherently fits the data better, measures like the Bayesian Information Criterion (BIC) account for model complexity and still favor MSPN. However, we will not further pursue model selection here, focusing instead on using MSPN as an exploratory tool to understand how system

Specific parametric assumptions are needed to implement the information processing models described in the introduction. For present purposes, we introduce various simplifying assumptions. First, in our face classification task, the stimuli vary along two second-order configural features: eye-to-eye separation and lips-to-nose separation. We denote the two: Dlips-to-nose and Deye-eye. Individual subject scaling analysis is used to create perceptual values that are equally spaced on a psychophysical scale. Therefore, a reasonable simplifying assumption is that the psychological representation of the stimuli lies on the 4×4 grid structure illustrated in Figure 1.

We further assume that associated with each stimulus are two normal distributions of perceptual effects, with the perceptual effects along Dlips-to-nose, along the x-axis, and Deye-eye, along the y-axis, being statistically independent for each stimulus value. The means of the distributions are set at 1, 3, 5, and 7 respectively, for stimuli on Dlips-to-nose and likewise on Deye-eye. All stimulus values have the same variability along Dlips-to-nose and likewise for Deye-eye. To allow for the possibility of differential attention to the component dimensions, or that one dimension is more discriminable overall than the other, the variance of the distribution of perceptual effects is allowed to be a separate free parameter for each dimension, σx 2 and σy 2 , respectively. Figure 1, left panel, shows the two axes with two separate normal distributions associated with each stimulus value.

To implement the perceptual-sampling process that drives the random walk (Figure 1, right), the observer establishes a decision-bound along each dimension, Dlipsto-nose and Deye-eye. Response criteria, +A and -B, representing the amount of evidence needed for making an A or a B decision on each dimension (Figure 1, right panel, associated with each random walk) are also established. A scaling parameter k is used for transforming the number of steps in each random walk into milliseconds.

Each model assumes that there is a residual base time, not associated with decision-making processes (e.g., reflecting encoding and motor-execution stages). The residual base-time is assumed to be log-normally distributed with mean μR and variance σR 2 .

The serial self-terminating model requires an additional free parameter pser representing the probability that, on each individual trial, the dimensions are processed in the order lips-to-nose then-eyes-to-eyes. The parallel interactive model requires a

div.head: Appendix B Model Recovery Tests
div.p: To bolster the credibility of the MSPN model's assumptions, we sought to verify that the identified properties, specifically processing order and process dependency, are discernible in the fit to observed data without any ambiguity. The standard procedure for model validation involves simulating data from a parametrically fixed model with known characteristics and then fitting that model with the to ensure the parameters can be recovered accurately. This model recovery process ensures that the model aligns with the actual characteristics of the mental processes, reinforcing the validity of the model's assumptions.

For this purpose, we generated three distinct datasets: (1) pure serial, (2) pure parallel, and (3) parallel interactive, using the MSPN computational model. This allowed us to create three specific computational model cases by fixing the key parameters (pmod and pcross). The simulated dataset comprised a 6 x 9 stimulus configuration with two dimensions, varied factorially as per the study's design.
Here are the details of the fixed parameter:

div.head: Pure Serial Data:
div.p: This set was generated by fixing the processing order parameter to pmod=0, thereby eliminating any trials involving parallel processing.

div.head: Pure Parallel Independent:
div.p: This set was created by fixing the parameter for accessing parallel module pmod=1 eliminating any trials involving serial processing; also by fixing the interaction to be pcross=0, it disabled inter-item dependencies by preventing the exchange of evidence between parallel processing accumulators during data accumulation from memory representations.

div.head: Parallel Interactive:
div.p: This set was generated by fixing the parameters to pmod=1 eliminating any trials involving serial processing; also, by fixing the interaction to

div.head: Appendix C Quantitative Model-Fitting Comparisons for the Composite Face Task
div.p: We fitted the models to the data from Gao et al. (2011) by minimizing the weighted sum of square errors for both the mean RTs and proportion of correct responses for all experimental conditions across the aligned and misaligned between-block experimental conditions.
We used a modification of the Hooke and Jeeves (1961) algorithm to estimate the best-fitting free parameters in the models by minimizing the error:

where n=4 is the number of stimulus conditions, RTobs is the mean observed RT data for each condition n, RTpred is the mean predicted RT data for each condition, P(c)obs is the proportion of correct observed and P(c)pred for predicted responses. 500 is an arbitrary value use to weight the accuracy differences to approximately scale them to the mean RT scale differences.

We generated quantitative predictions for the mean RTs and proportion of correct responses using computer simulation. We generated 10,000 simulations of each individual stimulus. We additionally used 300 different random starting configurations of the parameter values for each individual model in our computer searches for the bestfitting parameters.

div.head: Appendix D Testing the Pure Serial Model with Variable Decision Boundaries and Its Effect on the Congruency × Alignment Interaction in the Composite Task
div.p: In our exploration of the pure serial model, we simulated an experiment to examine the effects of variable decision boundaries on facial feature recognition under different conditions within the composite task. Specifically, we focused on the parameter value, Dx, for the "relevant" facial dimension, which varied continuously in the same and different upper facial part conditions. To generate predictions for each stimulus, we performed 40,000 random walk simulations across the 4 stimulus types and 2 alignment conditions, resulting in a total of 320,000 simulations.

The outcome measures from these simulations include the probability of correctly recognizing when the upper facial features in stimuli are the same, ( ). We selected initial values that achieved above-chance recognition accuracy for the target item (the upper part; see Table D1). Simulated accuracies are shown in Table D2.

We found that a minor change in Dx across the aligned and misaligned conditions, while maintaining all other parameters constant (see Table D1), affected the predicted value of p(c) shown in Table D2. We next calculated the Congruency × Alignment interaction term, '=2.34.

Hence, we have demonstrated that changing a single parameter (Dx) in a strongly analytic, pure serial model can predict the hallmark signature of facial holistic processing. This raises some significant challenges in interpreting the Congruency × Alignment interaction as an index of holistic processing. We do note, however, that the size of the Congruency × Alignment interaction term may also depend on various other properties of the system, encapsulated by other parameters within the model.

div.head: Appendix E
div.p: Quantitative Model-Fitting Comparisons for the Part-to-Whole task

We fit the data from Tanaca and Sengco (1997) by minimizing the sum of squared errors between the observed and predicted proportion of correct responses for all Experiments (using upright faces, upright and inverted faces, and houses, respectively.
Parameters were estimated using a modified Hooke and Jeeves (1961) algorithm which minimized the function:
where n=3 is the number of stimulus conditions (isolated features, new configuration and old configuration ), P(c)obs is the proportion of correct observed and P(c)pred for predicted responses.

We used 10,000 simulations for each individual condition resulting in 30,000 random walk simulations. Furthermore, we used 200 different random starting configurations of the parameter values in estimating the best-fitting parameters. Best fitting parameters for each experiment are shown in Tables E1, E2, and E3.

div.head: Appendix F Quantitative Model-Fitting Comparisons for the Other-Race Face Experiment
div.p: We fitted the models to our other-race experimental data using the method of quantile-based maximum-likelihood estimation (QMLE) (Heathcote, Brown, & Mewhort, 2002). For each individual stimulus, the observed correct and incorrect RTs were both divided into the two sets of the following quantile-based bins: the fastest 10% of correct RTs, the next four 20% intervals of correct RTs, and the slowest 10% of correct RTs (and for the incorrect RTs correspondingly)
We used a modified Hooke and Jeeves (1961) algorithm that maximized the multinomial log-likelihood function:

where Ni is the number of observations of stimulus i (i=1,n); fij is the frequency with which stimulus i had a correct and an incorrect RTs in the j'th quantile (j=1, m); and pij (which is a function of the model parameters) is the predicted probability that stimulus i had a correct, or incorrect, RT in the j'th quantile.
To consider the differing number of free parameters for some of the models, we used the Bayesian Information Criterion (BIC;Wasserman, 2000). The BIC is given by:
where lnL is the (maximum) log-likelihood of the data; P is the total number of free parameters in the model; and M is the total number of observations in the data set.

The model that yields the smallest BIC is the preferred model. In the BIC, the term P•ln(M) penalizes a model for its number of free parameters. Thus, if two models yield nearly equivalent log-likelihood fits to the data, then the simpler model with fewer free parameters is preferred.

For each stimulus, we generated 10,000 simulations resulting in 4 × 4 × 10,000=160,000 random walk simulations for the entire data set for each individual subject. We used 1000 different random starting configurations of the parameter values to estimate the best-fitting parameters.
